1925,Mike_Wilson@ca.ibm.com,2006-06-12T18:26:01Z,6,0,"Q: Do we even need ""Go Into"" style navigation any more?

Almost everyone is now familiar with forward/back arrows in the context of browsing the web, and our use of them (in the main coolbar) matches peoples expectations (including having historical context in a drop down). These, plus the pop up based navigation mechanisms (Open Type, Quick Type Hierarchy, Quick Outline, etc.), have made navigating around in a large data space relatively easy in Eclipse.

The only other value of the ""Go Into"" support was to make only a subset of the content viewable. The working set support in Eclipse can also be used to do this. Setting a working set that matches the content is both more flexible than ""Go Into"", and shows the ""parent nodes"" in the tree, which gives you the context you were looking for. Unfortunately, the workflow around setting/clearing working sets is still somewhat clunky. If we could fix *that*, I would argue that it's time to remove ""Go Into"" and the associated arrows."

1925,dak2009@gmail.com,2007-07-25T21:02:28Z,7,0,"Even when the workflow becomes less clunky having the ""Go Into"" feature is a great feature that is used constantly in our seismic processing application. We would miss it."
1925,Mike_Wilson@ca.ibm.com,2007-07-26T12:17:00Z,8,0,"Thanks for the note, David. Can you describe a bit more about how it fits into your normal workflows?"

1925,dak2009@gmail.com,2007-08-28T15:49:47Z,9,0,"We use the resource plugin to manage our seismic project files. Users work on various projects, sharing 100,000+ files, a terabyte of data per project and decades of CPU time.
A project is broken down into segments that are represented by an IFolder. Each user works on an IFolder. They use the navigator ""go into"" feature to isolate themselves from others work.

Extremely large projects could involve a few thousand IFolders and take 12 to 18 months to complete. Anything that helps reduce the number of files in the navigator view is greatly appreciated by our users.
I would love to see the working sets API improved so our user community would use it more but even with that the ""go into"" is still a fast/easy way to isolate an IFolder.
The ""go into"" feature is the Robertson screwdriver in our growing kit of resource management tools."

1937,unknown63@eclipse.org,2001-10-11T02:22:38Z,0,0,"I do not have a real test case for this.  I can only make one up.
The ""delete"" action always targets the active part.  If you activate the navigator and
then click on a file, the delete action will be enabled.  If you click onto another part
without a selection provider the ""delete"" action is disabled.  It is targetted to the
Now create a global action in an action set.  It should be enabled for type IFile, and
label it ""delete too"".  If you activate the navigator and
then click on a file, the delete action will be enabled.  If you click onto another part
without a selection provider the ""delete"" action is NOT disabled, because the plugin action
does not receive notification of the new selection.  It is still targetted to the selection
The current behavior of ISelectionService as implemented in the workbench is faulty.

column2: - If getSelection is called when the active part does not have a selection provider getSelection
- If the user activates a part with a selection provider a selectionChanged event will
be fired containing the part selection.
- If the user activates a part without a selection provider a selectionChanged
event will not be not fired.

column1: This leads to an inconsistenty.  The return value for getSelection has changed, but no event was fired.
To resolve this I would like to fire a selectionChanged event whenever the active part
changes.  If the active part is a selection provider we will pass the part selection.  If not
we will pass null in selectionChanged.  This indicates that the selection is ""undefined"" ( the
part may have a selection but is just not publishing it ).  In either case selection listeners are
notified when a change of selection occurs, and listeners always know the latest value of
selection may be null. I recommend adding an explanation to ISelectionService re: when

1938,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2002-06-19T16:53:42Z,5,0,"The offending code (which cannot be fixed without breaking many existing
* Modifies the value for the given property of the given element.
* Has no effect if the element does not have the given property,
* or if the property cannot be modified.
* Modifies the value for the given property of the given element.
* Has no effect if the element does not have the given property,
* or if the property cannot be modified.
* Note that due to an implementation bug (#1938), an SWT Item
* can get passed instead of the model element.
* Unfortunately, fixing this bug would break most existing implementations
* of this method which now assume an Item is always passed.
* To work around this in a safe way, use:
* @param element the model element or SWT Item (see above)
ICellModifier.java with changed spec for modify"

I have started fixing this but I ended up with the following problems:

column3: i) There are few different scenarios:

column5: Closing a window or closing all pages in a window.

column3: ii) Editors may or may not make sure the content is in sync when editing the

column2: a) When closing a single editor or a page, editors with the same input may be
opened in another page. Whether  it should be saved depends on isSaveOnCloseNeeded().
b) When closing a window, editors with the same input may be open in another page
in the same window (it would be closed as well) or is a different window.
c) When closing the workbench, editors with contents not in sync may be opened
and the user should be told and decide what to do.
We could fix a) and b) but we need API in IEditorPart to implement c)."

column2: To me, these detach window seem like ""palettes"" (if this was a graphics editor). A few
years ago, I remember using one such product on the Mac which implemented its palette
in a very helpful way - and it was done that the user did not even notice (the way a ui should
be...not interfere with what the user is doing)
Right now, the detach window always ""float"" above the workbench window. This means
you are always shuffling windows around. Here is how this graphics package handled
this case. When you were working with the palette, it was above the editor. Once your
mouse left (or it may have required you click on the editor again), the palette would
move below the editor (in the Z-order that is). When the mouse entered the palette
and hovered for a specific amount of time at the same place, the palette came to the
top...without the user clicking on it.
Maybe we could do something along these lines for our detach windows?

column2: I'm certain this functionality was added for the Tech Preview so somewhere along the line it has gotten lost.
It is not enough for the preferece dialog to save its store since each of the individual pages may have their
I believe the dialog used to get the strore from the pages and do a if (needsSaving) save call.
We can no longer do this because the dialog deals with IPreferencePages not PreferencePages.
The best solution would be to add a saveStore method to IPreferencePage.

column1: The minimal breaking API changes would be to
This is possible, although it seems more likely that clients are subclassing
the standard implementation PreferencePage and PreferenceStore.
Since the problem is severe enough, the change should proceed and
document as a breaking API change.
A client that is currently reimplementing PreferenceDialog.handleSave()
to save the preferences (as recommended in old javadoc comment) would
not be calling the new method implementation. If all clients should only
extend but not reimplement this method, this would be an additional
breaking API change and should be documented as such. If, on the other hand,
it's fine for a client to reimplement, then this is not a breaking API change.

column2: StructuredViewer#setSelection(ISelection, boolean) comment claims to not do call updateSelection(ISelection)

Comment out of date or implementation oversight?
Some code is relying on this to update viewer selection and notify listeners when table selection is tweaked,
Should find better way of doing this, and make this match the spec.
We have overridden the method so that we are not doing spurious updating on ""selection""
of the same selection.  A fix would just remove the need for our code.
I'm curious as to the use case that was causing problems.
Who sends setSelection often enough with the same selection to make it worth filtering out duplicates?

column2: The window closes but nothing should happen.
On ESC, SWT gets an WM_KEYFIRST message, which gets processed by Display.translateTraversal,
which ends up calling traverseEscape() on the focus control (the navigator's Tree in this case).
Its default behaviour is to close the control's shell, unless the shell has no parent.
Can't hook a traversal listener since we the focus control is arbitrary.
Could create it without a parent in DetachedWindow's constructor, but then the detached window
would act as a separate window, not a child of the workbench window.
E.g. it would not minimize when the workbench window is minimized.
Filed 1GE8RXW: SWT:WIN98 - Need a way for child shells to disable ESC closing
This would be a good candidate for an SWT patch."

Headline:  Import: Select Type does not select anything
Description:  In the import wizard, the Select Type button does not select anything.
- select File System for import source and press Next
- enter a directory with subfolders and files (eg. WINNT)
- in the Select Types dialog, press Select All and press OK
- Nothing was selected in main wizard
- All the files with the file extensions in Select Types should be selected.
NOTE: Select Types only filters the selected files if all the files were already selected.
TC (7/23/01 3:43:06 PM) - this was a design decision for import. Select types is a filter on the
existing selections and will not query files that are not selected for efficiency reasons.
TC (7/24/01 9:50:43 AM) - I think a rename of the button for the import dialog like Filter Types

column2: A better solution is to make Select Types actually select the chosen types.
Since this may lead to significant work by the UI, it should use a cancelable progress monitor
(also for Select All case, or even checking individual items).
Renaming the button for 1.0 is not very tasty, since the UI would likely change back for 2.0,
with progress monitoring and cancelation added.
Should just document the problem in README."

column2: Pls talk to me before you make changes.
After talking with the Core team and Eclipse Java IDE team, here are some of the issues:
- Everyone is ok with the words Build and Rebuild All. So I see no need to rename these. Woo Hoo!!!
- What is leading to confusion is the menu name Project. Everyone seems to think it maps to the
current selected project in your navigator! So they assume Build and Rebuild All apply to the
selection. What we need is a new name for this menu so it is less confusing (I'd be interested what
the usuability tests say). Workspace cannot be used unfortunately. Any suggestions? It could be
- It seems most people turn off auto build... I've not asked why yet...
- Everyone wants a shortcut to do a manual incremental build of the CU. Right now, hitting Ctrl+B
causes the incremental build to run on all projects. Therefore, you need to find the project, popup
its menu, and select Build - quite painful and causes you to scroll the navigator around a lot. The
package view adds ""Build Project and Rebuild Project"" to the file and folder popup menu... not so
sure I like that idea. What if we had a menu item in the File menu to do a Build with Ctrl+B as the
accelerator. It would be enabled when an editor is open. We could also change the Build toolbar
icon to also enable/disable on an editor being open? That way people get the shortcut to build the
project in which the current editor input belongs to.
- Some disagree with the Build menu item in the Project menu being removed when Auto build is
turned on. We should only disabled it instead. I defer to the usuability experts on this one...
Issue number 4 (shortcut to do project build) is what everyone seem to be complaining about.
Maybe if people used auto build more this would not be such a big deal."

The behaviour should be the same as if you clicked on the next row.
This currently activates the cell editor.
When you get to the end, it should not wrap.
Shift+Tab should cycle the other way.
Note that currently you can navigate in this way using <esc>, <down arrow>
1998,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2003-02-28T20:10:58Z,6,0,Should implement using a traverse listener on the TableTree.
1998,airvine@ca.ibm.com,2003-03-06T16:20:44Z,7,0,Navigation of the properties sheet is done via the arrow keys, not the tab
keys.  Bug #32627 addresses the issues associated with navigation via the arrow
keys, namely that you get stuck in a cell editor.
Key navigation has been changed such that arrow up/down will move you up/down
without activating a cell editor.  Pressing enter on a cell editor will
activate it.  You can then either press enter or tab in the cell editor to
accept the change, or escape to cancel.  Arrows can then be used to navigate
up/down appropriately.  Arrow right/left expand/collapse the tree.
Tab navigation cycle between the view, its folder tab, and the toolbars.
Attached is a patch that would allow tab navigation if in the future we decide
to pursue this avenue.  Note this algorithm provides the same functionality
already provided by arrow key navigation.

main tasks, each having its own subtasks, it is probably better to list all the
and then draw a checkmark in front of each task text as it has been completed.
Progress indicator can still be used to show progress within each of the main
I didn't check IProgressMonitor in detail, but it should be flexible enough

main tasks. Otherwise, the indicator will be too tall.

2009,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:24:27Z,0,0,"We need to sort out the proper handling of out-of-synch resources.

column2: - if you try to open one in an editor, you get an error dialog and have to manually refresh local
- on startup, if it tries to open an editor on an out-of-synch file, you get a cryptic error dialog

column1: It's debatable whether the user really cares if it's out of synch.  There's only ever one copy of the contents anyway.
One option would be to refresh automatically on open.
We still have problems handling out-of-synch resources.
For issues related to opening editors, see 1GDFD96: ITPUI:WIN2000 - Need to sort out handling of out-of-synch resources
There are other issues with copy/move, etc.
Many moons ago, when I was still on the Core team, you told me the way you thought this should work, but I've unfortunately forgotten the details.
For opening editors, I'm inclined to just do a refresh local, without prompting the user.  There's only one copy of the content anyway.
My only hesitation is that this is a workspace modification, and will trigger a build when opening an editor on an out-of-synch file.
For saves, it should prompt whether to overwrite, or to refresh.  It would be nice to be able to compare changes too.
Neither overwriting or refreshing is too tasty though, since changes are lost either way.
Is there any way we can leverage the local history or the recycle bin to avoid permanently losing changes?
If you're too busy, just let me know and I'll go ahead with my proposal above.  It may be suboptimal, but it will be better than what we have currently."

column2: The dialog does not open at the correct path as
was specified in the location field.
This has to do with using forward slash (/) instead
of backward slash (\) on windows. A PR was reported
to SWT about this (for DirectoryDialog). If SWT
is not willing to support this, then we will need
to fix it in the wizard.
We should also be using IPath::toOSString to get
the correct slash for the platform.
Should just fix our stuff, and not wait for SWT.

column2: specifying the location. However, there is one strange

Type in project name (p1 for example)

Now, open the new project wizard again
Leave the location field alone (it should contain the default eclipse dir)
Type in project name (p2 for example)
==> It creates a project with the contents from the dir\p2 directory.
We should probably not allow the user to specify the eclipse directory
when Use Default Location is unchecked.

column1: 2016,simon_arsenault@ca.ibm.com,2002-02-01T21:28:55Z,3,0,"If the perspective was already open when the workbench started, then the newly
added action set will no be shown. If you open the perspective in another
window, the action set will be visible. The only exception to this last point
is if you had saved over the default perspective (i.e previously opened the
perspective, made changes, and selected Perspective > Save As using the same
perspective to save changes to). In this case, opening the perspective in a new
window will still not show the new action set. You need to ""reset"" your
This behavior is listed in the html documentation for action sets extension
Since there is no support to know when a new plug-in is added, there is no way
for the Workbench to add the action set provided by the new plug-in."

column2: When inspecting an expression the debug view flickers and redraws quickly.

Check for DebugEvents in DebugView.  Maybe an extra one, or maybe a stray 'change' event.

column3: Launch some simple program in debug mode with a breakpoint set

column2: In AbstractTreeViewer.updatePlus(), set a breakpoint on the 3rd line -- boolean removeAll = false;
First time breakpoint is hit is for JDIThread and DebugView is OK.  Second time is for JDIStackFrame, and
DebugView is now entirely blank.  This seems to be source of flicker.  The entire tree should not be getting
removed, only the subtree rooted at the JDIThread should be getting refreshed.
Sent email to NE for advice.
Also flickers if you choose Display instead of Inspect (note that Display also appends to the same line; see 1GENIVH).
Seems to be the way the debugger is using the viewer.
I set breakpoints in AbstractTreeViewer.internalRefresh(Object) and TreeViewer.setSelection(List).
Here's an outline of what it's doing:
- stack frame changed not equal, so preservingSelection() loses it, and selection is cleared
- same thread, so selection is not lost
- same thread, so selection is not lost

column1: Runnable>.run() in findDebugPresentation(Object, String, String, boolean)

column2: - same thread, so selection is not lost

column1: Runnable>.run() in findDebugPresentation(Object, String, String, boolean)

column2: - same frame, so selection is not lost
- same frame, so selection is not lost

column1: Runnable>.run() in findDebugPresentation(Object, String, String, boolean)

column2: - same frame, so selection is not lost

column1: Strange that it's getting multiple SUSPENDs, and refreshing each time.
I noticed that DebugContentProvider.doHandleDebugEvent() has code in the case for RESUME to return
if it thinks the thread is suspended.
In the sequence above, on the first refresh, the selection is lost because the selected stack frame
has been replaced by a different JDIFrame instance (for main), which does not compare equal
(even though they both represent the same frame), so the viewer cannot preserve it across the refresh.
But DebugContentProvider and DebugView.autoExpand cause several refreshes, and cause the selection
to be changed to the thread, then back to the (new) frame.
The flicker is caused by the combination of the first refresh losing the selection, and the DebugContentProvider
changing the selection to the thread, then back to the frame.
The viewer can't do anything about the first case, since it has no way of knowing that the frames are the same,
The flicker may not be noticeable if DebugContentProvider could be changed to simply refresh (ideally just once),
then select the new frame, without  selecting the thread in between.
Note that the multiple refreshes, although inefficient, are not themselves the cause of the flicker
(aside from the first one losing the selection), since the TreeViewer is ""smart"" about reusing items
and not changing labels unless necessary.
Although not indicated above, it was also refreshing the variables and inspect viewers multiple times.

column2: I think the multiple suspends are due to the fact that we do not process the resume if
>the selection is lost because the selected stack frame
>has been replaced by a different JDIFrame instance (for main), which does not compare equal
>(even though they both represent the same frame)
in the LeapFrog debugger frames would compare equal in this case.
Anyway it is too late for such changes.
This explains the stack frame flicker - but the threads & debug target (i.e. all parents),
are still equal, so they should not flash."

2028,Kevin_Haaland@ca.ibm.com,2002-01-25T17:39:27Z,2,0,Pls include this in your ""Improved Servicability"" task. "
2028,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2002-01-25T21:52:27Z,3,0,"The exception returned by Core (with the message ""problems deleting resources"")
is a multistatus.  The children of the multistatus indicate that there are files
out of sync with the filesystem.  This is indicated by the status code of
IResourceStatus.OUT_OF_SYNC_LOCAL, and by a message to the user.
In build 20020125, this information is correctly revealed in the UI if the user
clicks on the ""Details"" button.  So it looks like the main servicability problem
has been addressed since this PR was entered.
For a nicer user experience, the UI should detect the OUT_OF_SYNC_LOCAL case,
and then prompt the user with something like ""The project has changed in the
filesystem since the last refresh.  Delete anyway?""  If the user clicks yes,
then call delete a second time with force=true.  This will force deletion
regardless of whether the filesystem is out of sync with the workbench.  I
wouldn't recommend forcing deletion without user interaction, because files may
have been added in the filesystem that the user forgot about.  Silently forcing
deletion in that case could mean lost work.
2028,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2002-01-28T15:49:14Z,4,0,"Filed separate bug 8592 for review of how we handle out of synch resources.

when the project content is deleted and a contained resource is out of sync."

In VAJ and VAME, selecting a compilation unit opens an editor.
For the user, this is just one click, or they can use arrow keys.
Currently in Eclipse the user has to double-click to open an editor.
I would really like a preference to enable the following behavior:
I think this behavior should occur when a compilation unit or any part of it
is selected (i.e. class in hierarchy, method, package & var decls, etc).
The behavior would ideally be consistent across all views, i.e. including
search, debugger, etc. as well as all java views, including compare.
So for example if the user expanded a tree in the packages view to see
a list of methods and then selected a method, the CU editor would open;
or if the user clicks once on a method in search, an editor opens, etc.
I understand that there will be times when an editor can take a while to open.
I am willing to put up with this because most of the time I will be opening
java files, and they come up fairly quickly."

* Verifies that the given name matches the given
* wildcard filter. Returns true if it does.
public static boolean verifyNameMatch(String name, String filter) {

column2: //We should be using real wild care checker, not this one - that is lacking

column1: This implementation is incomplete for the following reasons:
1) It does not take into account more complex wild card patterns (including those containing '?'). It can only
match cases like ""*<name>"" and ""<partial_name>*"" (and the fact that I wrote it does not help :-)).
2) It does not support exact match (if I want to register a contribution against ""plugin.xml"" only). I would
need to set my name filter to be ""*plugin.xml"" or ""plugin.xml*"" to fool it.
This code affects several extension points including pop-up actions and property pages (those
that are contributed against an object onto which name the filter is applied). It should be fixed
because it is a non-breaking change and no API is involved.

column2: Problem 1 is actually a feature request and can be deferred to future releases."

2041,dj.houghton@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:25:11Z,0,0,"I commonly die a horrible death because of the following SWT error. (no more handles)

column2: This causes other programs (like Notes) to look weird when trying to draw icons, etc.
In a common day I have to reboot my machine 3 or 4 times to ""reclaim"" all lost resources.
See 1GE8K2O: ITPUI:WIN98 - GDI usage stats for opening perspectives
ImageDescriptor.createImage() is spec'ed to always return a new image,
so it can't return null, and can't return a shared image (i.e. the missing image).
And it can't be changed to catch the out-of-handles SWTError and create a new missing image,
Only alternative is to change all cases to use ImageDescriptor.createImage(boolean),
and handle the null case and SWTError.
SWTError states: SWTErrors should not occur in typical programs, although ""high reliability"" applications
Could change ImageDescriptor.createImage(boolean) to catch the SWTError for the out-of-handles condition
(SWTError has a code), and have it return null.  So this would avoid the need for all users to catch it.
Of course, it would be better not to run out of handles in the first place, but we can't control this in general.
We can only minimize the number of images we create.
Your proposal makes sense. Hold off making these changes until the SWT team fixes their part of this
problem. They are going to be releasing changes that significantly reduce the number of images that need
Try changing ActionContributionItem to not create extra images on Win98: disabled and hot image.
Use the hot image as the regular one."

2053,eduardo_pereira@ca.ibm.com,2002-01-17T19:16:39Z,3,0,"Here is the two e-mail from me and David explaining why we should not change
I would recomend to close this PR without any change. The options to solve this
brings more problems then it solves and the gain it not good enough.
Closing it. Please reopen if you think that work should be done or if you need
I have added printlns to time part creation, page creation, plugin startup as
well as used optimize-it to try find the reason for implemention any of these
options. I concluded that I would have the proposal to be voted and I would be
I am convinced that ""Defering Part Creation"" should not be implemented. Giving
the user a better startup time and make him pay the price latter is not a
Option 1 would be easy for us to implement but would be a problem for ISV
Option 2 would introduce problems in the APIs like findView and getViews. The
time spend writing/implementing propasals on how to do this breaking change
could be better used in something else. IMO.
Option 3 the current implementation is not creating the controls anyway. So
the gained time is not that much. (I have timed it).
The big reason not to do it is stated in DS's last 3 lines.
While you were away Eduardo investigated the idea of deferral of part
creation.  Then he talked with me, and we formed the following opinions.  It
would be incorrect to defer control creation.  It would be of little value to
1. Defer control creation in non visible parts.  If this approach is taken,
each part must perform a null pointer check in every public method.  If any
method is called, and the control is null, the part must implement some hack to
answer the method correctly.  We only see this problem for
IWorkbenchPart.dispose, because we are the workbench.  However, this is not a
local problem.  The view can be accessed at any time, just by calling
IWorkbenchPage.findView.  If the view has any other public methods, they must
also be protected.  This is not part of the view contract, and it would be a
breaking change to impose it now.
2. Defer part creation in non visible parts.  If this approach is taken, the
page must consider ""part init state"" in every public method.  It is not
appropriate to misrepresent the parts within the page, just because we wish to
defer their creation.   For instance, if findView is called for a part which
hasn't been created, we must create the part and return its handle.  If
getViews is called, we must also create all of the parts and return their
handles; the result of this method should not be dependent on the init state of
the page.  The getViews method in particular will be called as soon as the page
is visible, because we use it to populate the Perspective > Show View menu.  We
can implement this algorithm, but it will have no performance impact.
3. Defer creation of everything within a non visible page.  If this approach is
taken, we might be able to defer part creation, assuming that none of the part
centric methods of the page area called.  However, if the loss of context
proposal is approved, we will discourage the use of multipage mode, and this
Regardless of whether 1, 2, or 3 is taken, the results of the optimization will
be very dependent upon layout.  We cannot predictably determine the improvement
We also have one big issue with the idea of lazy creation.  By introducing lazy
creation, we will also introduce staggered delays.  For instance, it may take 5
seconds to switch to an invisible view in a tab folder.  It may take 10 seconds
to activate a page.  From a user perspective, we are not convinced that this is
an acceptable behavior.  It would be better to accept the startup cost at
2053,eduardo_pereira@ca.ibm.com,2002-11-21T15:11:45Z,4,0,Reopening to mark as fixed. Views, editors and perspectives are lazy

then the highlighting has a different width between the two views.  This is noticeable when switching between them.
E.g. try switching between the Properties and Outline views.

2058,Kevin_Haaland@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:25:33Z,0,0,"In the import wizard, when you invoke Select Types you can use '*.' to filter files without
an extension.  This does not work in the export wizard.
Additionally, if you invoke Select Types a second time you will notice the dialog automatically
formats the extensions (i.e. '*.java' is reformatted to 'java').  So *. is reformatted to a null string
so if you click ok without making any changes it will not retain those files without extensions.
1) create a file in your OS without an extension 'test'
2) in Eclipse do an import on file system
3) in the directory field, find the parent directory of 'test'
5) click 'Select Types' and type '*.' in the 'Other Extensions' text field, click OK
you will see the '*.' is now '<null>,'
7) don't make any changes and click OK again
JEL (07/06/2001 2:25:09 PM) This PR can likely be given a low priority, I don't think many users
will be using files with no extension, even then the import wizard is still usable."
2059,philippe_mulet@fr.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:25:34Z,0,0,"It does not feel right that we do not re-ask the password for an existing CVS
connection in between session. In case I gave my workspace to someone else,
he would become granted with all access rights suddenly, just because I left
This should maybe be configurable at least, so I can flush the information.

column2: This supported is provided by the password keyring mechanism in Core.
It was decided that as a lowbar the UI would not support clearing it (you go and delete it).
Clearing on startup would need to be provided by Core.
This is either a Core or UI PR, depending on which solution one believes is right.
The core support is explicitly support for authentication information across sessions.
Clearing on startup basically defeats the purpose of the mechanism.
This information is, by default, kept with the workspace.  For whatever reason it was
decided that we would not expose a notion of login or user etc so the previously entered
passwords are automatically available.  The only options to address this real issue are:
#1 is unlikely to happen.  #2 while potentially feasible, is likely low on the priority list.
Don't know where to go from here.
This feels like a future PR for UI to support ""Clear password cache"" menu operation.
This is keeping with what we agreed in planning.
We at least should ensure that people know where to find the keyring file to delete
(Core should provide info to DOC/Kerri for June release).
Moving to VCM.  There were questoins last week about the flush API so I assume that VCM
is adding some UI for clearing the password info.  The documentation on how to use that
should go with the rest of the VCM doc.
We are not adding at this time.
General password management should be supported by UI but decision was to hold off for June.

2066,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2002-12-10T03:42:03Z,7,0,When showing the Tasks view, should also select and reveal the first new
problem (i.e. the marker in the delta that has kind ADDED, is a subtype of
PROBLEM, and has the earliest creation timestamp).
It's better to select the earliest problem rather than the latest, since
earlier problems can generate further secondary problems.
Need to be careful to properly handle edits in the Tasks view itself.  This
will work if we only check for PROBLEMs, which can't be manually added,
The view should not activate for CHANGED problems.  I know of no actual cases
where problem markers get modified after the fact, but this can occur if,
during creation, a marker is created then modified in separate workspace
operations (an easy mistake to make).  That is, the plug-in calls
createMarker, then setAttribute[s], not wrapped in an IWorkspace.run.

2066,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2002-12-17T15:30:23Z,18,0,"Currently we avoid opening the Tasks view -- it only is brought to front if it
is already open.  My thinking here is that some perspectives are not for
development but rather deployment or other activities, and having the Tasks
view opened in these perspectives may not make sense.  On the other hand, if
you're doing these other activities, you're probably not doing builds.
Erich or Darin, have you received any complaints to this effect with the
Console?  It would probably be better to make them consistent, then if there's
an issue, we can address it for both.
- show when new error or warning, but not info
- bring to front (opening if necessary), but do not activate (same as Console)
Also moved code to Workbench from WorkbenchPlugin to address bug 28512
(still needs to be moved up to org.eclipse.ui.views)."
2066,erich_gamma@ch.ibm.com,2002-12-17T20:20:28Z,20,0,">Erich or Darin, have you received any complaints to this effect with the
there were indeed complaints, in particular when the console was brought to
front for any output (a web server can provide lots of output). It was
addressed by a preference ""show on error/show on output"".
It looks like auto revealing is highly sensitive due to the loss of context and
some users simply might not want it.
The initial setting should be to reveal the task view since the motivation for
this effort was that first time users find the task view.  "

2086,dejan@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:26:11Z,0,0,"This is a warning from PDE team that PDE starts the platform by running UIMain class
using the currently selected JVM. In other words, it is not running soon to be implemented
1) When PDE users start Eclipse instance to test or debug the code they are developing
in design-time Eclipse instance, they will not get anything provided by eclipse.exe.
I don't know what it is (so far I know it might be the splash screen).
2) If there is any secret handshake between eclipse.exe and the platform UI, the platform
should be ready to NOT receive when PDE launches UIMain directly. If it only
boils down to the splashscreen, the platform should have an option to raise
I don't know about other possible consequences of PDE's running of UIMain instead
of eclipse.exe, so please fill in the blanks.

column2: The UI is not going to be displaying the splash screen any more. Showing the splash
screen is moving to eclipse.exe and product configuration level. Product.ini is also
moving out of the ui plugin as well.

column3: Basically, all that eclipse.exe does is run java with a particular set of arguments.
As long as PDE is prepared to provide those arguments, there should be no problem.
I suggest DG talk to JMcA about what those arguments should be."

2088,Kevin_Haaland@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:26:13Z,0,0,"Propose we add a ""Too many errors, bailing out"" feature to the build process, and/or
perhaps a max cap on the number of tasks the Task View UI is allowed to contain.
Simple errors can easily cause the task list to become huge and unmanageable.
I've seen task lists containing tens of thousands of entries because of simple mistakes.
Well, what am I going to do with 100,000 entries anyway?
The list takes about 30seconds to load and if you have filters on, then
it takes about the same amount of time to update as you select different
files in the properties view.  Since this operation occurs automatically
for you, and cannot be aborted... it's a bit of a pain -- and it could take you
15 minutes just to fix a one-character mistake in a library path or something. =(

column2: 6) Select some other file in the project.
This is actually quite important. We need this ""feature"" or something like it.
Our problem on the SWT team is that when we load the swt project from the repository,
it does not initially have a .classpath file. (because our .classpath is platform-specific,
so we create our .classpath file after loading). After a build, there are 20,000 errors or so.
On Windows, the ""only"" problem is that it takes forever to populate the Table widget.
On Linux, we crash. The Table widget can't handle the volume.
You can imagine that if autobuild is on and someone innocently loads the swt project
on Linux (this has happened more than once) they will crash.
Changing the platform of this PR from WIN2000 to ALL, and removing the DCR from the title.
Why don't you simply hit the Cancel button ? I understand that an auto-cancel action would be nice, but this could be handled by the platform.
Cancel is insufficient as you don't always get enough realtime feedback from the
compiler to know when to cancel.  Moreover, without an auto-cancel option or a
high-water limit on the number of permissible tasks in the Task view, loading, refreshing
and filtering the Task view can become a significant burden on the system in terms of CPU
time and memory resources.  Hence cancelling manually midway through a build could still
leave 10000 errors behind (it does not take long for them to accumulate) and may cause
deteriorated application (and in the extreme case, system-wide) performance.
Nonetheless, I believe the issue can wait until the next release as it does not
occur frequently in normal operation.  It may be a source of concern for those people
migrating existing code to our product as things can sometimes be quite ""broken"" in the
first stages of any migration until all the compiler options and build paths get
FYI, I just timed a compile that had 30,434 problems.
This was extremely easy to do, because if I load all of SWT and its examples and internal examples
at one time with ""autobuild"" on, and then go away for a coffee, this is exactly what will happen.
(because SWT intentionally does not have a .classpath file).
It takes under 2 minutes to compile all of that stuff, but populating the Tasks view's Table
(which is a native Table widget, therefore we cannot fix it) takes over 6 minutes.
The feedback problem from the compiler is a JDTCORE bug, which we already have a PR for.
Now the 6 minutes update is a UI issue. Moving to UI land for archiving.
I want a faster table widget."

column1: 2090,Kevin_Haaland@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:26:16Z,0,0,"At the moment it is possible to maintain multiple workspaces under
Eclipse by specifying -platform to the application.  However it is not
possible to switch between workspaces without shutting down Eclipse
or starting another application instance in parallel.
From the user standpoint, it would be nice if the following workspace-related
functionality were available from within the Eclipse UI (much like it is in VAME):

column2: - multiuser development on the same machine [esp. useful in eXtreme environments]
- rapid deployment snapshots (for setting up local build environments within a team of developers)

column3: [the different semantics of developing in Java, C++, HTML, JSP may impact the
manner in which a developer would structure their user interface, in terms of
which action sets are loaded, and which types projects will be displayed together]

column1: 2097,jerome_lanneluc@fr.ibm.com,2001-12-19T10:30:48Z,2,0,Can we get a fix for this?"
2097,eduardo_pereira@ca.ibm.com,2002-02-11T21:59:21Z,3,0,"We have changed the code that handle exceptions in the event loop. It is doing
a better job but OutOfMemory is not always possible to handle. We may not even
have memory to do the catch block.
It should work better in ""99%"" of the cases."
2097,jerome_lanneluc@fr.ibm.com,2002-03-04T11:51:53Z,4,0,"What about an option to NOT catch this exception at all? If I check this
option, I wouldn't mind letting the VM exit as long as I can see the stack
2097,eduardo_pereira@ca.ibm.com,2002-03-25T16:15:49Z,5,0,"1) We are trying to avoid options. Too many option makes things dificulty to
manage and to reproduce bug reports, etc.
2) I have reproduced two diff cases:
i) The user code is allocating big chunks of memory. In this case the
stacktrace is shown and it is usefull.
ii) When the OutOfMem happens allocating a small object. In this case we do
not have memory to run the catch block but the stack trace may not help the
user anyway because the place it failed to allocate may not be the same as the
one that is allocating to much memory."
2097,jerome_lanneluc@fr.ibm.com,2002-03-25T16:22:28Z,6,0,"Thanks for the explanation Eduardo. I now know that if I don't see the stack
trace, it is a case of a VM that was started with too small a heap."

2099,richkulp@us.ibm.com,2002-08-22T14:11:23Z,4,0,"It would be even better if it was full filter support like the rest of the

the most sense and is consistent with most of the other filter functions in
Plus the filter setting should be stored in the preferences for the
propertysheet plugin (or somewhere like the other viewers) so that they will be
persisted. It is annoying to select a set of preferences, and then have to do
this each and every time I come up.
But for short term, the bug itself is that the filter list does opposite of
what it is supposed to do, as noted in the original text of this bug. It should
be default of Filter out expert, not show all. The logic currently will either
show all or show all but expert. When expert is not filtered, you still want to
see all non-expert plus the expert, otherwise you want to see all except
expert. You don't want the case where it shows ONLY expert.

2110,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2002-01-27T18:58:47Z,2,0,*** Bug 2622 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***"
Save the selected page (its id) between invocations in the same session.
Save the expanded state between invocations in the same session.
Do not save the selected page between sessions.
This avoids eager plugin loading since the default page (""Workbench"") is
provided by the Workbench. (It also avoids having to handle missing plugins.)
Do not save the expanded state between invocations in the same session.
The expanded state is uninteresting if the selected page is not saved.
2110,knut_radloff@us.ibm.com,2002-02-04T21:44:48Z,4,0,Bug 7790 is a duplicate of this bug and was fixed today.
In 7790 Nick writes that the active page should be persisted across sessions.
I fixed this bug (and bug 8981) to only remember the last page within one
The advantage of persisting it is that the fix is localized in the
PreferencesDialog. My fix adds API to the PreferencesDialog to return the
current page id and to create a PreferencesDialog using a page id for the
The disadvantage of persisting the last visible page is the eager plugin
loading pointed out by Nick above."

2147,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:27:24Z,0,0,"Here are some GDI resource usage stats for opening perspectives.
Coming up with no perspectives open: 75% free
Open resource perspective in other window: 62%
Open another resource perspective in other window: 48%
Open a third resource perspective in other window: 35%
Close window with no persective open using close box: 36%
Close window with resource perspective using task tray menu: 49%
Close window with resource perspective using task tray menu: 63%
Open resource perspective in other window: 51%
Open resource perspective in other window: 37%
Close window using close box: 51%  -- worked this time
Close perspective in last main window: 75%
Open java perspective in other window: 52%
Open another java perspective in other window: 30%
Open a third java perspective in other window: 7%
Close java perspective in other window: 30%
Close java perspective in other window: 51%
Close java perspective in other window: 75%

column2: - images are loaded multiple times for multiple perspectives
- images for a perspective are freed properly when perspective is closed
- Java perspective has more overhead for first Java perspective open
- Java perspective has significantly more overhead when opening a new window.
probably due to having more toolbar buttons and menu contributions than the resource perspective
- can only have max 5 resource perspectives open
- can only have max 4 Java perspectives open in same window, or 3 in different windows
Just for fun: Notes takes 10% to come up with the mail window, plus ~2% for each open message (freed when message is closed).
Workspace contains single empty Java project.
Opened Resource perspective in same window: 73%
Opened 2nd Resource perspective in same window: 67%
Opened Resource perspective in new window: 72%
Opened 2nd Resource perspective in new window: 62%
Opened Java perspective in same window: 69%
Opened 2nd Java perspective in same window: 59%
Opened Java perspective in new window: 69%
Opened 2nd Java perspective in new window: 59%
This is improved from 110, but still too much"

2148,Mike_Wilson@ca.ibm.com,2006-04-12T19:58:22Z,9,0,"Depending on the plug-ins that you are running, and the size of the dataset, opening a project can be an expensive operation -- I know of one case where it could take >2 minutes -- and have multiple side-effects. It is better to require an explicit operation (pop menu; select open project) for things like this, than to bind it to double-click, which is easy to generate accidentally."

2149,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:27:27Z,0,0,"In task list, hit create button 5 times.  It takes a couple of seconds to complete.

column2: Auto-build was off, so it's not due to builder activity.
Was in Java perspective, with another Java perspective open in same window.
Close java perspectives, and tried in resource perspective.
It was faster, but still felt sluggish for deletes.
Suspect it's due to delta processing in packages view, tasks view and navigator view,
with packages view taking the most time for showing problem ticks."

in the navigator.  To avoid this I open up new perspectives on

new perspectives.  I never do any real work in it.

column3: Title: ""cvs over ssh - one project locks the workbench: netscape.exe - Application Error""
Msg: ""The instruction at ""..."" referenced memory at ""..."". The memory could not be ""read"".
When I clicked ok, netscape was terminated and I ended up with a blank editor tab.

column2: Follow up: I double clicked the html file again and got an error dialog box: ""an error occurred when

column6: opening this editor"" and the workbench died.

column1: 2 org.eclipse.ui 2 Problems occurred when invoking code from plug-in: org.eclipse.ui.

column2: While the crash might very well be a Netscape bug. We should handle the crashed editor better.
Moving to UI for consideration on exception in MenuManager.
From the stack trace it looks like we are trying to update a pulldown within
NegativeArraySizeException =  Thrown if an application tries to create
I am confused.  Within MenuManager we don't allocate any arrays.  The only
allocation is a ""new ArrayList"" (see below).  If some inline optimization is performed
the error may occur in the ArrayList constructor where a real array is allocated.  But that
implies that ""items.length"" < 0.  According to the java spec ""length may be positive

column3: protected void update(boolean force, boolean recursive) {

column6: // clean contains all active items without double separators

column2: We also call menu.getItems further down in the method.  The getItems method will
query the system to determine the item count for the menu.  If an error occurs in
OS.GetMenuItemCount the result is -1.  Then menu.getItems tries to
allocate an array of size -1.  This probably causes the exception.
The netscape editor opens  in an OleEditor, so it will replace some pulldown menus
within the window menubar.   It is not clear how MenuManager.update will cooperate if
Hypothesis # 1: The menubar contains a combination of our own menus and those
contributed by netscape.  MenuManager.update removes all which are unknown.  And
our own pulldown menus which have a menu manager ( probably the case above ) may
not be ""realized"".  Either type of pulldown menu may return -1 if OS.GetMenuItemCount
Hypothesis # 2: Kevin says there is complete separation between the ole menu and
our own.  In my own testing I find that we can normally query the items in our menubar
even when another menu is active.  The error situation above may just be a
side effect of the netscape error.
OLE creates its own menubar which it super imposes on the applications menubar.
The ole menu bar is completely separate from the applications menubar.
The only entries in the ole menu bar that come  from the application are those provided
Is some cleanup being done on the MenuItem objects passed in to these methods?
We may modify the contents of these menus while the ole editor is active.  For
instance, we may add items to File New or the Perspective menu.
I talked with VI about this.  It should be OK to modify the contents of our menus while
an OLE editor is active.  And in my own testing I am able to modify the actions which
appear in the menu ( via action sets ) with no problems.
Getting back to the original problem, ie the workbench died without putting up a dialog,
our menu bar is corrupted.  There is nothing we can do.  At least we log the
problem.  We can do a readme for this scenario.

column1: 99.1.1.1 If an OLE editor crashes, it can cause the Workbench to also crash
If an OLE editor crashes, this can cause the Workbench to either crash, or to have its menus become inconsistent."

2176,Kevin_Haaland@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:28:00Z,0,0,This exception occured shortly after creating a new Java editor in Eclipse as
a result of deleting a line of text by selecting it with Shift-End and hitting Delete.

column2: For the Eclipse impaired, what do you mean by ""creating a new Java editor""?  Double
clicking on a *.java resource?  Also, is this error reproduceable?
This actually looks like a Eclipse java editor problem, not SWT StyledText.
As Knut suggest it appears that style ranges are being set for bogus lines.  setStyleRange(StyleRange range)
sends getLineAtOffset for the range.start and rangeEnd (range.start + range.length), so it appears that the
input StyleRange for setStyleRange has bogus values.  Moving to ITPUI.

column2: The element has been selected by code (treeviewer.setSelection()) while the viewer was in background.
When brought to front the selection is not visible, but seems to be set anyway (and prevents from being selected again)
It has to be something with refresh. When the hierarhcy gets a new input, the changing is not done by changing the input of the tree viewers
but by calling refresh on the viewer.
Seems to work OK the first time the hierarchy view is opened.
Try again, selecting different type in packages view (to hide hierarchy view) and choosing Show In Hierarchy.
Reproduce in JDK build on 98, and in VAJ on 2000, with hierarchy view in either
top-down (""type hierarchy"") or bottom-up (""supertype hierarchy"") mode.
SWT bug, encountered due to AbstractTreeViewer reusing items in updateChildren().
See 1GELNIG: SWT:WIN2000 - Tree item selection not shown if same item previously cleared"

- in Navigator, select A and create new folder B
- it works, and in the filesystem it has recreated A, under which is B
Is this as it should be?  I think this behaviour is actually preferable to giving an error dialog.
But maybe it should warn that the parent folder has been deleted, and offer to recreate it,
giving the user the chance to cancel it.
Otherwise, it feels like the environment has discovered that it was out of synch, but hasn't bothered
to tell the user.  If there were other resources in the parent, they would still be showing in the navigator,
but would not exist in the filesystem.  If it prompts, it could do a refresh local too if the user accepts recreating the parent.

you need to start another drag gesture to restore the view to its original place.

column1: - the selection is cleared, and C.txt has focus
- the selection is cleared, and A has focus
When an element is deleted, the next sibling should be selected.
If there is no next sibling, the parent should be selected.
If there are multiple items selected, it should use the focus item to decide which item is selected next.
That is, the next sibling of the focus item (after deletion) or its parent if none.

An alternative would be to show the progress in status bar so that it is less

2229,aleb@delsyne.ro,2002-03-29T22:59:28Z,3,0,"You could measure the time taken by the save operation and store it.. At the next save operation, if the stored time is > 2s you show the progress dialogue.. and store the new time."
This one is important to us, since it is on the critical path for incrementally
Not showing this dialog would significantly improve the perceived performance
2229,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2002-05-26T19:10:18Z,5,0,"We've encountered some stumbling blocks in being able to do this.
Things are complicated by the fact that Save is done in the UI thread.
Reducing priority since this is not a stop-ship.
2229,erich_gamma@ch.ibm.com,2002-05-26T19:54:34Z,6,0,Then could save use at least the progress bar in the status line provided by
ApplicationWindow? This would also reduce the flicker.
BTW, this progress bar should use an Eclipse style stop icon (the one that is
currently shown was manually crafted during the LeapFrog age)."
2229,erich_gamma@ch.ibm.com,2002-05-26T20:22:43Z,7,0,"If the problem is that Save is run in the UI thread than another solution is to
check the elapsed time on each progress tick and to only show the progress
dialog after some elapsed time. To handle the case of a long no progress tick
interval an SWT timer could be used."
- it disables the window (everything but the shell itself), so it will lose
- the disabling does not currently cover the shortcut bar, since this is not
- ProgressMonitorDialog blocks input anyway, so this is not a major loss
- we can fix the shortcut bar problem
Also, note that we cannot use an SWT timer if we're running in the UI thread,
since it requires the event loop to be running.
2229,Adam_Schlegel@oti.com,2002-05-27T17:40:50Z,9,0,ApplicationWindow.run uses get/setEnabled methods on the various components of
the window to disable them during the operation. However, these methods lose
the current keyboard focus. There does not appear to be the necessary API to
If the user is making changes in the current editor, and then saves via Ctrl+s,
it is inappropriate to take keyboard focus away from the curent editor. This
amounts to an even worse usability problem than presently exists."
2229,Adam_Schlegel@oti.com,2002-05-27T20:38:05Z,10,0,"I have compiled a more detailed summary of the problems encountered in trying
2229,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2002-05-29T19:06:53Z,12,0,"I have released Adam's patch to use the status line progress monitor for save.
I also changed the icon to a better one we had lying around (will double-check
Erich, could you please try it out.  You will need to load our changes from
There are some known layout problems which we want to fix up.
The progress bar and cancel button appear on the right, after the Java editors'
status line contributions for Writable, Insert, and cursor position.
They should appear to the left of them, taking up the right side of the message
area without moving the other contributions.
2229,erich_gamma@ch.ibm.com,2002-05-30T10:14:26Z,13,0,Tried it - incremental builds feel now much faster. This is great progress!
- other top-level shells are not disabled only the application window. If a
build takes longer you can start a second build from another workbench window
and you will deadlock. In LeapFrog we had code that disabled all Shells to
handle this case. Dirk wrote the code and he is trying to find it again. This
approach has worked well in LeapFrog.
- since incremental builds are fast the appearance looks like flicker. Showing
the progress after some elapsed time (2 seconds) would help. The check-the-
elapsed-time-on-a-progress-tick should work. To handle the case of no tick for
an extended period you could use a timer thread.
If the disabling problem is fixed then we would like to use the progress in the
status line for other actions as well (e.g. opening a type hierarchy, opening
the all types dialog). Is there any reason to not doing so?"

column1: 2229,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2002-05-31T13:42:55Z,15,0,"Adam is already looking at disabling other windows.
We will also see what we can do about flicker.
As for using it in other places, I'm concerned about different operations using
different progress monitors.  I think it would be confusing if the user could
not predict where a given operation would report progress.
If it's just save, it's predictable.
But, if you think using it in other places makes sense for JDT, go ahead.

2229,Adam_Schlegel@oti.com,2002-05-31T20:35:41Z,19,0,"There is a fix for the multi-window deadlock problem in the repository.
I am still working on the flicker. There already is a 1/2 second delay
associated with showing the progress monitor in the status bar. The delay can
be made longer by default, but there will always be ther case where we get
flicker when an operation takes just a little longer than the delay.
If this code is going to get wider use, it might be worth making it so that the
progress monitor tries to guess if it is going to flicker based on the amount
of progress that has happened so far."

column2: Should really change Action to do this for the caller who specifies ""ALT+ARROW_UP"" etc.
Currently it keeps the given accelerator text in verbatim.
Accelerators should be specified as constants, not as strings in the text,
and JFace should insert the accelerator text as necessary in pull-down menus (not in context menus or menu bars).
The current solution is not workable for multiple languages.
Too late to change JFace API.
Could change existing API to map existing keys to proper English words (and enable other languages)
Must also change accelerators ALT + Arrow Keys conflict with native combo box."

- It appears the only difference is that one works on the selected object and the other remembers what the last ""Go Into"" was on.
- There is no icon for ""Go Into"", just for ""Go Forward""
- It seems a waste of a popup menu entry to have both ""Go Into"" and ""Go To"".
For larger ""products"" the navigator menu could get long, and ""Go Into"" is an infrequent operation also supported by toolbar icons.
Q: What's the difference between ""Back"" and ""Up""?  The tooltips are unhelpful.

column2: Go Into is not the same as Forward.   Up and Back are also different.
Go Into changes the input to the current selection.
Forward goes forward in the history (opposite of Back).
Up changes the input to be the parent of the current input (independent of the selection),
adding to the history rather than going back in the history.
Back, Forward and Up work similarly to Explorer.
There's no icon for Go Into, because I felt that toolbar icons should apply to the whole view, independent of the selection.
Go Into and Go To are separate entries because I didn't want the user to have to select Go To, then Into.
I agree Back and Forward will likely not be used from the menu often, but they are there for completeness.
The Go To menu would have to be there anyway, for Go To / Resource."

column3: I might be missing something obvious here, but how can you make a perspective window
move in front of (cover) a detached view window?

on a search result and go back to the code, hiding the search results in the background.
Currently, the search window stays in the front of the z-order, even if it looses focus.
Maybe this should be a Workbench Preference option that the user can select.

2260,carolynmacleod4@gmail.com,2001-10-11T02:32:30Z,0,0,"There are several places in the UI where the user uses a dialog to specify filters:

column2: 1) Click the 'Filter' tool in the Tasks view toolbar.

column3: Notice that the dialog that comes up says: Show entries of type
Notice that checked items in the checkbox tree will be *SHOWN*.

column2: 2) Click the little down arrow menu in the Navigator or Packages toolbar, and select Filters...

column3: Now here, the dialog says: Select filters to apply  (this could be confusing to users - does 'apply' hide or show?)
And the checked items in the list will be *HIDDEN*.

column2: It would be more consistent if the Navigator/Packages filter dialog said something like: Show files of type
and then the user would know that checked items in the checkbox list will be shown.

column2: The managment of multiple open editors is still a severe usability problem. A common
practice is to do a close all editors periodically. There were several proposals for how
to address this issue and I don't want to repeat them, but I'd like

column1: (essential)  An easy hot-key (e.g. NOT something so acrobatic as ctrl-F6) to
toggle between editors in most-recently-used order (such as Windoes ALT-TAB).
(nice) A way to ""tear off"" editor windows like is possible with other windows.
Personally, I loved VAJ's class-browser with its own window, and it's own
Taskbar (on win32) icon.  That's how I did _all_ my editing.
2261,eduardo_pereira@ca.ibm.com,2001-11-29T20:40:32Z,2,0,This is a problem that we are working on now.
Ctrl F6 was changed to switch editors as the Windows Alt+TAB and Ctrl F7 was
A dialog was added to enable the user to manage all editors (Menu>Window>Switch
Editor). From this dialog you can close, save, view recent closed editors and
switch to any editor in any perspective.
The concept of re-using editors as also added to the workbench. The
preference ""Number of open editors before reusing"" is in the workbench
preference page and once ""N"" editors are opened the oldest editor (in the
activation order) is reused. A ""Pin"" button was added to the toolbar so the
user can ""PIN"" a editor which will not be reused while pinned.
This work is still in development but is already released in the 2.0 stream.
Any feedback is appreciated. We think editor management is important and is
difficult problem to solve and we would like to see any new idea from users.
I was a VAJ user as well and used/loved the ""VAJ's class-browser"". I think you
can get the same behavior by changing the preferences ""Workbench->Open a new
perspective in a new Window"" and ""Java->Open new type hierarchy inside the
2261,eduardo_pereira@ca.ibm.com,2001-12-04T19:10:18Z,3,0,"*** Bug 1829 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***"
2261,p.hinsch@blue-orange.de,2002-01-31T19:41:57Z,4,0,"How about using the shortcut CTRL-TAB instead of the ""acrobatic :-)"" ctrl-F6?
That's at least the common shortcut under Ms-Windows for cycling subwindows of
Another idea according to the problem with the limited tab-area vs. many open
How about extending the tab area to multiline instead of a scrollable tab area?
As used for example in Textpad (if according setting is activated).
Or how about an extra ""editor selector view"" like the outline- or tasks- view?
That kind of view could even provide the luxury of showing the komplete file
path or the complete class name (including package) of all editor windows."
2261,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2002-02-01T16:36:31Z,5,0,"The editors dialog is similar to what you describe, but it's a dialog not a
view.  It also needs some work (table column widths are not persisted).
We can't use Ctrl+Tab for cycling between editors since Ctrl+Tab is the
standard key for cycling between controls in the tab order when Tab is taken
(i.e. by the editor in this case).  This gives access to the toolbars, which we
I agree that Ctrl+F6 is awkward though."
2261,eduardo_pereira@ca.ibm.com,2002-05-30T20:04:02Z,6,0,"Resolving as later. I don't think we will find (try to find) another
accelerator for Ctrl+F6. The original problem was solved with the editors
dialog, a close all saved action and the Ctrl+F6. "
2261,eduardo_pereira@ca.ibm.com,2002-09-05T18:03:31Z,8,0,"Closing the report. Will discuss editor managment a bit more in the bug 22301.
I don't think we will change Ctrl+F6 since we could not find something else but
the user will be able to configure it once we implement the keybinding UI."

2263,Kevin_Haaland@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:32:45Z,0,0,"This should probably move to SWT, I will let KH decide.
When exporting to a JAR, the user must enter the extension manually.
1) Make sure you have a project in your workspace
5) where it says ""Where do you want to export resources to?"" click
6) you will get a save dialog, ensure *.jar is selected for ""Save as type""
7) enter a file name ""myProject"" (without including an extension), click Save
The expected behavior is to save the JAR as 'myProject.jar', instead it is saved
If you goto export again, you will notice the combo box remembers your previous
save, but it added the .jar for you this time.
To see the expected behavior, run Microsoft Word; goto Save As... and enter a file
without the extension, the file will save with the .doc extention.

2265,daniel_megert@ch.ibm.com,2011-01-24T14:53:56Z,8,0,"I also updated the icon reference doc."
I have noticed while using the version label annotations that getLabel() is called with
very high frequency in the navigator.  It seems like it might be doing excessive work.
The VCM label decoration isn't too expensive, but when invoked frequently, it may contribute
to general loss of responsiveness in the UI.
For example, just changing the selection in the navigator asks for the labels again.
Also, during notification phases, getLabel is called frequently.
Thanks, I'll take a look.  It shouldn't be doing this just when the selection changes,
unless one of the selection listeners on the viewer is interested.
Actually, it might be the forward/back/up buttons updating their tooltips.  But I'll investigate."
2266,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2002-01-26T03:31:47Z,2,0,Tree viewer refreshes are not efficient.  Should revisit.
2266,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2002-12-04T18:30:17Z,3,0,Initial viewer population and refresh now only obtain the label at most once.
Please let me know if you see otherwise.
hasChildren can still get called twice, but this is harder to fix.
In the case of VCM, hasChildren should return true if the element -can-
contain children (i.e. if it represents a folder), and not do the work of
going to the repository to see if it actually does have children.

failed so the widget was not disposed. Somehow, someone disposed the widget prior to

column1: 2300,Tod_Creasey@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:33:35Z,0,0,"If you open a file with its system editor, you will not be able to export the file as it is not
in sync.  You will get an error ""Zip file must have at least one entry"" which is not the case.
If you do a refresh from local, the export will work.
Quick fix: Have a more generic error message ""Error(s) exporting.""
1) Do a refresh from local for all projects automatically when the user selects 'Export...'
2) Do a refresh from local for a single project when the user selects, expands, or checks the
Refresh from local is executed very fast when there are no files out of sync with the system
so I don't think the cost of doing this each time you export is that drastic.
It wouldn't hurt to pop up the Refreshing dialog to indicate to the user why the CPU is chugging
if there are many changes to catch up to.

column2: Auto-refresh is not a good idea. Builders may run.

column1: 2300,Tod_Creasey@ca.ibm.com,2002-04-16T19:07:08Z,2,0,It is not uncommon for user to have to refresh from local for a variety of
operations - hacking the export dialog for this case would make for
Before entering the export wizard, the user should be prompted to save their work.  There is a good
chance the user is planning to export the file they are currently editing and could easily forget to save.
If they are exporting, the user rarely checks the contents of the jar/zip so the exported work may not
1) open a .java file in a project
2) make some changes to the file, don't save
4) select the java file you were editing, export to your desktop
5) open the java file, note that your changes are not in the file

column1: 99.1.1 Pop-up menus stop working when detached view is reattached
When a view is initially created as a detached view, then is reattached to the main workbench window, its pop-up menu no longer works.
The workaround is to close and reopen the view.
The problem does not occur when a view is created in the main workbench window, then is detached, then is reattached.

match(...) should match the whole string.  find(...) can find any occurrence.
A pattern of """" should only match the empty string.
For example: new StringMatcher(""ab"", false, false).match(""abz"") is false,
so new StringMatcher("""", false, false).match(""z"") should be false too, but it's currently true.
This is due to the segCount == 0 test, which should check whether there are actually wildcards before returning true.
The next two tests check for empty target and empty pattern, but they're not currently reached.
I also noticed another bug, where if ignoreWildcards is true, it doesn't check the length.
So new StringMatcher(""a"", false, true).match(""ab"") currently returns true, but it should return false.

column4: return (end - start == fLength) && fPattern.regionMatches(fIgnoreCase, 0, text, start, fLength);

column2: The GlobalBuildAction is contributed by ITPUI and not JDT. There isn't a lot
of data in this PR. In general ISVs should not catch runtime exceptions but let them
propagate to the platform where they are handled. Moving to ITPUI.
I suspect this is NOT one of the null message problems we were seeing with Status objects
unless someone's IStatus implementation is being more premissive and generating a string.
The standard Status will assert that the message is not null"

column2: For views that are private or that we want to prevent users from creating via the Perspective -> Show View... option
[i.e. we only want to open them programmatically] it would make sense for the Workbench views extension-point to
provide a ""hide"" attribute in the XML schema.
This is the case right now with a set of SWT examples that open views.  We have a launcher view which
supplies ancillary functionality related to the example views (Descriptions and Import source code). As
such it is not necessary or desirable for the user to open these example views manually.  Moreover, leaving these
views hidden would reduce clutter in Perspective -> Show View...

is now a part of the regular downloads.

Window -> Preferences -> Workbench -> Work in Progress
The win32 implementation uses file-system callbacks for notification. The linux
implementation uses FAM. All other platforms use a polling mechanism.

column2: For ActiveX Contols, you can make use of one of the IPersistStorage interfaces

column1: I am using the IPersistStorage mechanism as shown below.  I can investigate the IAdviseSink2 mechanism.

column2: // Get access to the persistant storage mechanism
// Are the contents of the permanent storage different from the file?
Pls followup with VI. There is API that we are NOT calling.
- We are not calling filePropertyChange when we save the text.
- We are not calling the SWT API isDirty() because there is not API to
add a listener to get a callback when the editor becames dirty so we
- The menu acelerators are not working (Ctrl S, Ctrl F4 etc).  (PS: The OLE
- MSWord gets dirty every time it is activated.
- The SWT API isDirty() works for MSWord and MSPaint but does not work with PPT.
About the original problem discribed in this PR.
The text is not being save because the editor being open is Wordpad not WinWord.
The fix for it is to change the method OleEditor>>#usesStorageFiles()
to use ""Word.Document"" instead of ""Word"" which is more WinWord specific.
Still need to fix the problem described in EJP (6/6/01 2:37:48 PM)

column1: 99.1.1.1 Editor dirty state not tracked properly for OLE editors
The dirty state for an OLE editor is not updated properly.  This also causes it to prompt to save the contents when the editor is closed, even if the contents
99.1.1.1 Workbench accelerator keys don't work when using OLE editor
Accelerator keys for Workbench actions, like Ctrl-S for Save and Ctrl-F4 for Close, do not work when an OLE editor is active.  However, the
corresponding actions in the pull-down menus do work.
Accelerators defined by the OLE editor itself also work."

2369,darryl@netbauds.net,2006-05-12T04:01:26Z,19,0,"This feature gets my vote.  But I have throughts more over on where this would be leading.

I regularly have Eclipse open permanently on my virtual desktop under Linux/KDE.  The only reason I restart it is when it crashes or locks up.  Currently I am happy with the reliability as my Eclipse will crash maybe once a week, however as you can imagine the state that gets opened is what I was working on the last time I cleanly shutdown (at least a week old).

To make things really cool it would be nice if there is a clean/dirty exit flag in the state info.  So eclipse can detect if it crashed, by marking it as dirty while Eclipse is started and only the File -> Exit function during shutdown marks it clean.
Then maybe as a feature on from this there was an automatic mode which detected it crashed before (when you next start it) and it offers to:
* Restore all state info (except editor views)

* Restore default state, ignores all state info and will clobber it next time state info is saved, at next exit/explict save (maybe this is not needed, or maybe this is like -clean, but the purpose of this function is a get out of jail option for the possibility of a corrupted state file from causing other bugs to get triggered that make Eclipse die during startup.  Maybe that clean/dirty flag should be tri-state to also record if Eclipse was still booting up at the time it last crashed out.

Then my next feature request would be automatic periodic intelligent background state storing, at least automatic updating of current open editors list.  As Comment #9 points out there is some form of value in platform perferences, which I have set to 5 mins, but it doesn't work as I would expect.
The current situation is a PITA at worst.
2369,Tod_Creasey@ca.ibm.com,2006-09-21T19:35:51Z,20,0,The question for me is if we should save the workbench or the workspace only.

Saving the workspace is pretty painless (most of you already do it every 5 minutes by default - see the Workspace preference page) but saving the workbench requires us shutting down and restarting the workbench windows so that any state plug-ins save on shutdown is saved (like when you change the positioning of the editor tabs).
The question for is it better to save more by restarting the workbench or to be less ""in your face"" but quietly saving the workspace in the background?
Personally I find the latter more interesting but you are the ones voting so please let me know your preference here before I proceed.
2369,Tod_Creasey@ca.ibm.com,2007-06-13T20:37:13Z,21,0,There are currently no plans to work on this but I would be happy to look at a contribution."

I rarely restart on my own, so when it does crash, I get an old workbench. I would love for it do auto-save the workbench as well as the workspace every n minutes in the background. It would also be nice to have a menu item to manually save the workbench. When I start it up I want everything just as it was, editors, perspectives, undo history, as much as possible. I apologize for making such requests with no real intention of contributing myself. I really appreciate you contributors who are reading this, especially the one(s) who will eventually implement this."

2369,darryl@netbauds.net,2009-02-12T16:26:08Z,24,0,"I don't want it to save files (like as per the File -> Save action).  That is for the developer/user to make their choice as to when that occurs.

But I would like it to save a versioned Local History of a file periodically in the background.  This would mean producing an MD5/SHA1 or other checksum of the starting file (when it was first opened and each time it was saved with File -> Save action).  This provides an absolute starting point to be able to trace history back to the original file.

Then keep the latest copy of open file data in some sort of private workspace/project area.  This is what would be periodically saved as per user preference we are talking about, 5 mins, 1 min, etc...  This is a bit like Microsoft Word temp files that are created when you open any document, in that file is also the redo/undo history of the changes that were made, this is allows MS Word to do ""automatic recovery of documents after a crash"".

I would also appreciate that the list of currently opened editors also be updated through this mechanism.  This can be ontained by virtue of the files that are registered with local history via this mechanism.
When eclipse restarts or opens the file again it should check to see if a copy of that file has an entry in the Local History and offer solutions to that situation:
* Open the file that was saved (ignore the history and throw the local history away).
* Open the file that was saved and replace the editor contents with the more recent data from local history (this marks the file as edited but not yet saved with the ""*"" next to the file name).

* If the copy on disc is newer and/or not the exact original copy the Local History started with then explain the findings to the user and offer to open both into 2 different editors, with the copy from local history not having any filename assigned to it but offering a default filename to Save As dialogs which would replace the original file.

I can not stress how important it is for all this stuff to happen asynchronously in the background, editing a file in eclipse and switching editors and opening a new file and saving a file already take long enough in eclipse that it can be painful at times and none of the above here needs to be done synchronously (i.e. don't hold up the GUI while doing it).
