2970,lynne_kues@us.ibm.com,2001-11-21T15:44:18Z,4,0,"We do not directly support this; however, one could do it via the
My initial thought was that one could set the key binding for tab and insert
spaces, but currently TAB is not defined as a key that can be customized.
So we could provide a new key binding for tab.  This would be more
straightforward for the application to handle (vs. ExtendedModifyEvent).  Or we
could introduce new StyledText API and handle it.
2970,knut_radloff@us.ibm.com,2001-11-21T15:47:22Z,5,0,The easiest solution would be to insert spaces whenever tab is pressed by
I assume that the user also wants existing tabs replaced with spaces when the
2970,lynne_kues@us.ibm.com,2001-11-21T16:00:18Z,6,0,"Knut is right, you can use the VerifyEvent to do this quite painlessly.  Just
replace the tab character with spaces in the VerifyEvent text field."

2987,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:47:19Z,0,0,"From EC post: ""Why do torn-off views always stay on top?"" by Simon Archer on Oct. 4, 2001.
When you tear-off a view so that it floats outside of a Perspective it
insists on floating on-top of all other Eclipse views.  Does anyone else
I'd like to be able to tear-off a view and have it fall behind the main
Are there any reasons for this not being an option?
It has to do with them being created as child shells of the window, rather
than being top-level windows in their own right.
This allows Eclipse UI and the underlying window system to manage them
e.g. menu and toolbar of the main window apply to detached views; minimizing
main window also minimizes detached views
However, torn off views do tend to obscure the main window.
1GLC4ZM: ITPUI:WIN2000 - EC DCR: Why do torn-off views always stay on top?"

We cannot auto-dispose controls which previously were not
disposed when the page's dispose method is called."

2992,hudsonr@us.ibm.com,2002-01-22T20:52:39Z,3,0,"""We cannot auto-dispose controls which previously were not disposed when the
I do no understand this comment.  Currently, we DO auto-dispose controls some
of the time, and we don't other times.  That is the point of the PR.
A page *must* dispose its control itself in the case where the EditorPart was
closed and the Outline remains open.  A page *must not* dispose its control
itself (because it is already disposed) in the case where the EditorPart
remains open and the OutlineView is closed.
So, the change will be non-breaking because all properly-written IPages already
dispose (unless already disposed) the Control when IPage.dispose() is called.
My concern is that developers do not check for control.isDisposed() in
IPage.dispose() because they never tried closing the OutlinePage while leaving

column2: Found that the failure occurrs on WIN NT & Win 2000, but not on Win 98

column3: 1FW76SX: IWT:WINNT - release of large imported jar takes several tries

column2: In some cases, users may experience problems when releasing a large number of
resources (>1000) while running the WebSphere Studio Workbench Java 1.2.2 Edition.
The problem occurs during a release and is made known to the user through a ""Problems""
dialog with the message: ""Problems occurred synchronizing the selected resources"".
The ""details"" of the problem indicates that a ""SeverException"" has occured.  In general
this problem is not fatal in that released and unreleased resources are consistent in
both the server and the workbench.  Re-releasing the resources which did not get released
Unfortunately, the cause of the problem is related to the a subtlety in the TCP implementation
in Windows NT (Win98 users will not experience this problem) which prevents sockets
from being reused effectively.  As such, immediately retrying the release operation will
not always work.  Users may have to wait until the TCP stack clears some unused sockets
before attempting to release the resources.  This may take a number (1-4) of minutes.
This is a severe problem for which we need to find a fix/workaround.

3000,rgobeli@prodigy.net,2015-04-16T16:11:55Z,6,0,"The problem is that there are two hidden attributes.  Eclipse has a hidden attribute and the file system has a hidden attribute.
These may be getting confused in the above comments.

In windows the Java system makes a file with hidden file attribute unwritable.  Here is the issue, the description file .project is hidden, when this file is imported form a Mac or Unix system.  The project name can not be changed, because the .project file is not writable.
At this point java makes the .project file unwritable even though the read only file attribute is not set.
This got changed back in version 1.5 of java.  Sun assumed that hidden files should be write protected, but that was not windows intent.

Windows just intended to make files hidden from the user so if they did not know the name they could not change them, but the windows system can still see the files and change them in the system.  The attribute to protect files is the readonly attribute in Windows.
So now there is this case where the .project file is not writable in a project that is loaded into a windows workspace from a different operating system.
This bug has already been fixed in the CDT system for .cproject files, but the .project descriptor file is used outside of the CDT system.  So CDT could not fix it.
I have made a patch to the file system resource manager to clear the file hidden attribute when the eclipse system tries to write to the .project descriptor file.
This patch attachment is loaded on bug 194216.  There does not seem to be anybody monitoring this bug, because I have not got any response for over a year.

The check for a windows system could be removed, because the unhidden descriptor file should not stop other systems from working correctly.  The Mac will just reset the hidden attribute.  No harm done.
The isWindows could be always true and only the three lines in the if statement are needed.  I have tested this on my windows machine using the latest Java and Windows 7.
added code below is added between the following lines of code in FileSystemResourceManager.java just before the descriptor file is written.
+              // For a windows system files need to be unhidden to be writable.

column3: // any time description file is written, make it unhidden in the filesystem.

This PR tracks the usability problem that the user has when he tries
to delete anything which is still held onto by the MS Windows Explorer.
E.g., when he tries to delete a solution and the explorer holds on to a
contained folder, the user has to perform the delete operation three
times (ignoring the error messages) to get rid of the solution.
We don't know how this can be handled in our code.
A workaround is to close the solution, delete the closed solution
(this works fine), and afterwards clean up things in the local file system
If it's not the Windows Explorer which caused the problem (but,
e.g., the HTML editor) you might have to exit the application before
you can delete the local files and/or directories.
This is a candidate entry for the README:
When deleting resources, problems occur if the file system object (file or folder)
for a resource is held onto, e.g. by an external application that has a handle to
a file or folder. Note that a resource can only be deleted if its members can be
A workaround for this is to close the resource's solution and then deleting files
or folders from the local file system. If the file or folder is being held onto by a
plugin, it might be necessary to exit the application to be able to delete it from
A closed solution can always be deleted. If the resource to be deleted is a project,
folder, or file, the ""Refresh from Local"" operation should be performed on the
solution after it is re-opened. If the resource to be deleted is a folder or file, it will
have disappeared from the workbench. If it is a project, the project can be deleted

column1: 3003,eclipse@abstratt.com,2003-03-17T19:10:55Z,1,0,"I have done some manual tests (since it would be difficult to automate such
tests) on Linux (NFS) and Windows XP (Netware).
1 - add linked folder/file pointing to a NFS/Netware directory/file;
Result on Linux: the refresh operation blocks trying to access non-available
directories/files. The operation can be cancelled though. 10-20s after
reconnecting the network cable, the operation completes successfully. In both
cases, no errors are presented to the user. The same thing happens when trying
to access those non-available locations using other applications.
Result on Windows XP: the refresh operation faces a short delay trying to
access non-available directories/files, and then proceeds. The operation
completes successfully (no errors are presented), the linked resources cannot
be accessed and are properly decorated as being broken (the children are lost,
and so are their meta data).
An way to distinguish if a directory is empty or there is I/O errors accessing
it is checking if java.io.File#list returns null. We could mark such nodes (and
its children) as problematic and not discard them when refreshing. We could
have a different flag to specify if this should be done or the nodes should be
discarded during a refresh local operation.
But do we want to provide such feature? It seems that nobody else (except us)

column3: This is the method related to the problem of having readers while calling

column1: ElementTree.immutable(). If this method is ok, we are safe."
3006,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2001-10-15T19:27:41Z,1,0,"This is a tricky situation.  The vulnerability is in the following two lines
Between the method calls to setRootNode and setParent, the tree
pointed to by ""parent"" will be inconsistent.  Any form of read
on the tree during that critical period will probably fail.  Note
that writes are not possible anyway because the tree must be immutable at this
point already.  The failure mode could be bad, as it could hit an assertion (for
example in DeltaDataTree#getChildNodes) that results in a runtime exception.  At
least such a failure would only affect the read that happened during the
critical region, and wouldn't leave the tree in a bad state.
This is expensive to fix.  Making it safe would require an extra sync block for
every tree read, where currently no sync block is needed.  This would slow down
So the final question is: do we make it safe, thus impacting performance for all
tree operations, or risk the rare failure and leave it as-is?  Since there has
never been a report of failure here, and it would only cause read-only
operations to fail (which by definition can't do much damage), I would suggest
3006,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2003-03-13T21:31:23Z,5,0,"Closing.  Although there is a theoretical vulnerability, we have never seen a
problem in practice in the two years since this bug was opened.

column1: 3009,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2001-10-30T21:10:23Z,2,0,I've released a fix that avoids writing the file in cases where it's empty,
which should prevent 99% of these files being generated.  I want to understand
more about how this is working before I make further changes.  It seems to do
- creates a file under the .metadata folder, which contains the path of an index
file in the TMP directory (c:\documents and settings\username\local
- writes cache information to this index file in the TMP directory.
This means that every new workbench you run, you get one of these cache files.
This of course includes workbenches created by tests, etc.  My TMP directory had
What I don't understand is why it creates that level of indirection.  Shouldn't

3009,klicnik@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-31T14:39:27Z,3,0,The platform URL cache is currently not being used, so your patch to supress
writing the file should in fact handle 100% of the current cases.
The intended use is when we are running Eclipse plugins from other than the file
system (eg. from http server). The current code stream does not fully support
this configuration (ie. will not actually work if you try it), but some of the
base core mechanisms were enabled. So the idea was to cache plugin jars and
other files for actual execution. Wanted to be able to make use of the plugin
jars/files regardless of what workbench you were running with (ie. single
Eclipse cache, rather than per-workbench). So there was a per-workbench index
written, but the actual files were cached only once (in the future wanted to
merge even the separate index files).
The problem is that we obviously did not take into account the various test
launchers (that create temp workspaces)/ continuous switching of workspaces with
self hosting. So each time you create a new workspace, new index is written.
Currently there are no mechanisms for managing the cache.
So back to your patch ... in 2.0 the index should always be empty because we do
not cache when running from ""file:"" URLs"

column1: 3014,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2001-11-13T16:17:22Z,2,0,Closing this PR.  A number of performance issues in this area have been
addressed.  Tree deltas are now periodically collapsed, resulting in smaller
snapshots.  I have been working for two weeks with resource debugging turned on
in my self-hosting workspace, and I have never seen a snapshot longer than
800ms.  More typically, it is around 150ms.  This is reasonable considering it
only happens every 100 top-level operations.  This time will also be
proportional to the size of the changes.  So if you're just stepping in
the debugger for example, snapshots will be small and fast.  Snapshot files on
disk seem to be reasonably sized after a day of development in the same

My preference is having write() method. No particular technical reason.

My tendency is to put it in a writer.  This way people can uniformly use their own writer

column1: 3017,dj.houghton@ca.ibm.com,2002-01-08T19:12:38Z,1,0,"Not a committed item on the 2.0 plan.
3018,dejan@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:47:57Z,0,0,"It is currently possible to register with the platform as a log listener. However, logs that
are dispatched are those from the moment of registration. PDE Error Log view needs to
show logs that happened before it was opened.
An API is needed that parses the current content of the .log file and returns
an array of IStatus objects. PDE Error Log could use it to display logs that
happened from the moment of the workbench startup.
PDE could write a parser itself, but there are two disadvantages to it:
1) PDE does not own the .log file.
2) It is not good to separate code that writes and code that reads the same
file format. Since .log file format is private to the Core, it has the privilage
to change its format without notice. All PDE cares for is to get an array

column3: - What should happen with the exceptions which are dumped to the

column4: log?  On parsing/reading the log we are not keen on somehow rebuilding the exception

column3: - In what form should the returned value be? (Status objects, strings, ...?)

column1: 1) Of course, it would be ideal if rebuilt status objects would not differ from those logged after
the log view has been activated. However, all I really need is the actual stack dump
of the exception, not the exception object ifself. If you could create an IStatus implementation
that will give me exception text instead of the object, I would be OK.
2) This is related to 1). Error Log works with IStatus objects, so an array of IStatus objects
would be ideal. On initialization, Error Log view would ask the Platform to give it all the
status objects that have been logged until that moment (including those during the boot).
These status object will be shown as the initial content of the view. After that new status
objects will be added on top as they are logged.
BTW, this feature will allow users to clear the log so that only new status objects are
seen as they arrive, but also to restore the entire log. For this reason, the method to
parse the .log file and return status objects may be called even during the lifetime of
the Error Log view (each time people press ""Restore Logs"" button).
3018,dj.houghton@ca.ibm.com,2002-01-08T19:14:15Z,1,0,"Not a committed item on the 2.0 plan.
Also note that there is discussion about converting the format of the .log file
to XML which then can be parsed by PDE or any other tools which are interested."
3018,dejan@ca.ibm.com,2002-01-08T19:48:49Z,2,0,"Could you point me to the discussion location?"
3018,dj.houghton@ca.ibm.com,2002-01-08T20:03:31Z,3,0,"See RFC 003 off the Platform Core team web space on eclipse.org.
Will re-open bug for now and consider changing the file format to XML so
clients are able to parse the file themselves."
3018,dejan@ca.ibm.com,2002-01-08T20:21:14Z,4,0,"A general concern with these types of problems is that ideally one who writes
the file should also read the file (or provide the mechanism to do so). That
way, changing the syntax of the file will not immediately break all the readers.
What is written into the file are status objects, so a class that reads the
file and converts them into status objects again would free you to change the
It is also general Eclipse practice to have only one reader for each XML format
(as opposed to several plug-ins being in the XML reading bussiness).
That said, if parsing XML is the best we can get for 2.0, I would take it :-)."
3018,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2002-01-08T22:25:45Z,5,0,"What you suggest is basically what I originally proposed, but it was changed
after the discussions in the platform core mailing list.  I've written a reader
for the XML log file, which I will certainly make available to anyone who can
make use of it.  That is, I would hand off the code as is, not make it part of
The question we didn't agree on in the discussion is how the reader API would
look.  There was interest in a wide variety of functionality for reading the log
(only reading the ""x"" most recent entries, only reading errors from certain
plugin(s), filtering by date, etc).  Rather than commit to a large chunk of API
for reading at this stage, I think it's better to just publish the DTD and let
others do the reading.  It's fairly straightforward to implement a SAX parser to
pull in the information you need."
3018,dejan@ca.ibm.com,2002-01-08T22:35:29Z,6,0,"OK then, just make sure the DTD is current AND you somehow provide
notifications when the DTD is changed."
3018,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2002-04-09T14:20:49Z,7,0,"Fixed.  The log file is now written in XML format.  The class PlatformLogReader
can be used as a template for implementing log reading functionality.  The log
file DTD will be published in the near future."
3018,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2002-04-09T14:27:00Z,8,0,"Also note that the method Platform.getLogFileLocation() has been exposed so that
clients can now know for certain where the log file is located."

Should we be deleting children automatically?
- have phantoms /proj/a, /proj/a/b, /proj/a/c (note: all have sync info)

- /proj/a is a phantom and is no longer synchronizing so

We will not allow the synchronization of subtrees. This is just
too expensive w.r.t. the deletions and garbage collection.
Currently VCM forces the user to synchronize at the project
With targets we will add to the API that if a user wants
to synchronize a subtree, then they must put sync info
on the parents of the tree."

column1: 3029,rodrigo@peretti.ca,2001-10-22T16:24:36Z,1,0,"The case sensitivity problem has already been fixed. There are some pending
Vlad and myself worked through the PDE discovery of external plug-ins
(plug-ins found in the installation of an Eclipse product that will be
We concluded that PDE will be fine if the following conditions are met:
1) There is an API on Platform similar to ""parsePlugins"" that can be
pointed to the Eclipse installation and will return a PluginRegistryModel
that includes installation filtering step. Basically, the API would answer
the following: for the input path representing the root directory/URL of
the Eclipse-based product, give me the list of plug-in models that the Core
will see when it eventually starts up the product. I will take the model,
call 'resolve' on it and take the final list of plug-in models that will be
presented to PDE users as valid external plug-ins for making dependencies.
2) When PDE comes to finally launch the run-time Eclipse, it may need to
further filter out the list of plug-ins if users turn them off in order to
override them with plug-ins in their workspace. PDE uses ""-plugins
<pde_working_file>"" for that. Vlad concluded that we need to ensure that
this option continue to work and that Core does not filter this list. You
can still resolve it, but filtering is not needed because filtering has
already been applied to creating it.
3030,dejan@ca.ibm.com,2002-09-10T18:14:58Z,2,0,This defect is obsolete. The boot loading is now controlled by platform

column1: 3032,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2001-11-05T16:04:53Z,2,0,Natures are currently configured at project creation time, or when a new nature
is added to the project using setDescription.  They aren't configured on first
open.  The current behaviour is consistent with all the API comments in IProject
One advantage I see of this approach is that it's slightly more consistent.
Otherwise, a closed project may or may not have its natures configured.
The original PR doesn't say WHY the behaviour should be changed.  We need a good
reason for changing API, so I'm closing this PR.
NOTE TO JEFF: feel free to resurrect this PR if you know of a compelling reason
why the current behaviour isn't satisfactory."

column2: The SecureRandom used on JDK is different from the one used in J9.  As a result, the database encrypted with
one, will not work on the other.  That is, you can't switch between JCL implementations.  The JCL team has no
opportunity to implement a byte-for-byte identical one as this requires implementation knowledge.
Propose that we include the JCL SecureRandom implementation in Eclipse.  This means that we would
supply our own implementaiton on all platforms.
Readme added.  Moving to deferred for future consideration"

3036,jeffmcaffer@gmail.com,2001-10-11T02:48:14Z,0,0,"Unzipped driver as root, tried to start eclipse as regular user.
After encountering many directory/file permission problems, i finally got to the point where it created
a .metadata area in bin/.  I noticed that there was also a dir structure called tmp/platform off bin/.
The user shouldn't need to write anything to the bin/ directory on startup - this dir is shared by many
other users on a multi-user system.
Just to be precise - i had to run eclipse from bin/ due to the way the eclipse startup script was structured.
I suspect that .metadata and this tmp/platform would have been created wherever i invoke eclipse.
If the user can start eclipse from his/her own /home directory, then this wouldn't have been a problem.
However, defaulting the creation of user-specific files to the /home dir or a location specified by a flag
(like the -platform flat) would be a good idea.

column2: This is being done by the PlatformURLConneciton class as part of the file cache mechanism.
The PlatformURLConnection just writes to whatever
path is returned by System.getProperty(""java.io.tmpdir""). Don't care where
it is, as long as the area is r/w.
I wonder if Java actually checks whether or not the location identified in java.io.tmpdir is
writable.  I guess the other problem is that several Platforms running the same install may
end up using the same temp dir.  Since the filename (i.e., .index.properties) is the same for
all, they will be trying to use the same file.  This may well cause problems.
Could the temp dir be moved to be in the .metadata dir somewhere?
it is less than optimal as the same file may be downloaded by several different running
platforms but it might be safer.
Each running instance of the platform should in fact have its own index (the files are actually
prefixed by a workspace-specific stamp ... see .cache.properties in .metadata of each
workspace). I wanted all the caches to use the same directory so we could optimize
the downloads (your point above), although the code to do this is not there."

plugin registry to a cache file, respectively, do not have any error checking.  They do
not pass a status back to indicate a failure.  As a result, a failure could occur leaving
a corrupt plugin registry without anyone knowing about it.
3038,debbie_wilson@ca.ibm.com,2002-02-12T19:40:19Z,1,0,"Registry caching will now fail if an unexpected byte code is encountered.  In
this case, a null registry is returned.  It is assumed that the cache is
corrupt so the entire registry will need to be re-read.
3039,debbie_wilson@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:48:17Z,0,0,Currently the class PluginParser uses a series of vectors called scratchVectors to hold temporary
information.  Using the objectStack instead of these scratchVectors could give us a performance
3039,debbie_wilson@ca.ibm.com,2002-01-16T18:25:10Z,2,0,All scratch vectors except those for extensions and extension points have been
removed.  These must remain as extensions and extension points can appear in

points, another extension, 4 more extension points, etc.).

3052,jeffmcaffer@gmail.com,2001-10-11T02:48:30Z,0,0,"There is no API way of limiting the total disk space taken by the Local History Store.
History stores are large because much of the space of index nodes is contained in keys that are
almost exactly alike.  The key/value data in the nodes could be compressed (using gzip) and split among
several relatively small newly defined ""blob segment"" objects.  This way, the storage used by a history would
An API should also be defined limiting the size of a particular index.  An exception or status could be returned
if an insert is attempted that would cause an index to violate its limit.  A number of entries limit would be easy to
enforce.  A byte limit would be harder."

* A mergeFactory is used to merge 2 indexes into one. One of the indexes
* (oldIndex) is on the disk and the other(addsIndex) is in memory.
* The merge respects the following rules:
* - The files are sorted in alphabetical order;
*   - if a file is in oldIndex and addsIndex, the one which is added
* is the one in the addsIndex.

3068,debbie_wilson@ca.ibm.com,2003-02-28T20:01:01Z,6,0,"The following is a code snippet from the method remove(HistoryStoreEntry
entry) in the class HistoryStore.  This code should be tried again after bug
Note that in order to fix this bug properly, we will also have to look at the
way the HistoryStore creates a counter to uniquely distinguish between states
for the same file that have the same last modified time.  Currently, the
visitor in addState(IPath path, UniversalUniqueIdentifier uuid, long
lastModified) just counts up the number of states with the same filename and
lastmod time.  It then assigns a count number that is one bigger than the
number of states it found.  If we remove some of these older states, we could
end up creating a new state with a filename, lastmod time and counter which
are the same as an existing state (the number of states is not sufficient for
determining the counter if some previous states are removed).  Note that on a
move for example, a new state is created with the new filename and the
existing lastmod time (not the current system time).
protected void remove(HistoryStoreEntry entry) throws IndexedStoreException {

column2: // Do not remove the blob yet.  It may be referenced by another

3070,Dave_Dykstal@oti.com,2001-10-11T02:48:55Z,0,0,"We need to find some ways to make the footprint of indexed stores smaller.  One way would be to compress
the data in an index node since much of the data is duplicated from entry to entry.  Another would be to decrease
the page size, but that would require a complicated conversion and the implementation of BLOBs.
3070,dj.houghton@ca.ibm.com,2002-01-08T19:26:32Z,2,0,Not a committed item on the 2.0 plan.
3070,Dave_Dykstal@oti.com,2002-09-18T15:22:54Z,4,0,"Indexed stores are used for two things -- history and properties.  One of the design points is that all
data be kept in one file -- hence the internal btree structure.  I don't think the property store
support built on indexing makes use of the transaction protocols so it might be better to do
properties in a different way that exploits the file system directly.
If the need is to just
cut back on store size then a way to do that would be to allow for blobs and let index nodes grow over
page boundaries if necessary -- this would allow index nodes to be a little sloppier before
splitting and the split criteria to be a number of entries rather than a page overflow page size.
This will result in pages being more fully utilized.  In addition, front-end key compression can be
used to minimize the space taken up by keys in index nodes."
3070,dj.houghton@ca.ibm.com,2004-10-29T13:29:38Z,5,0,"Won't change indexed store representation at this time."
3071,Dave_Dykstal@oti.com,2001-10-11T02:48:56Z,0,0,"Currently objects are limited in size to 6K, since they need to fit inside a page.  Find a way to make these
larger, perhaps by chopping them up into blob segments that can be assembled on demand.  An API addition
may be needed to allow streaming over these objects since copying them may be too demanding on memory.
Blobs could also be used as values in indices.
3071,dj.houghton@ca.ibm.com,2002-01-08T19:26:39Z,2,0,Not a committed item on the 2.0 plan.
3071,dj.houghton@ca.ibm.com,2004-10-29T13:28:57Z,4,0,"No intentions of changing the indexed store at this point in time."

3074,christophe.avare@free.fr,2004-06-08T15:37:31Z,17,0,It is sad that this issue will not be resolved soon.
This means that many librairies will not be available for the Eclipse platform.
Mainly, Jeff arguments do not take into accounts librairies whose licensing and
distribution terms restrict the way the code can be distributed.
For example the Java Advanced Imaging, Java3D and the like cannot be delivered
as plugins without breaking the binary license agreement from Sun.
More, many well known Open Source librairies are build and install themselves as
While, in this case, one can always provide an Eclipse packaging, this will lead
to many sources for the same librairies, the worst case being having to install
the same version of a given library one for feature X, another from Y, and so on.
Until there is a shared repository and a large effort from all the Java actors
to provide Eclipse plugins or bundles we will have to rely on external librairies.
I personally doubt that Sun will either change its licensing terms or distribute
its librairies as Eclipse plugins in a foreseeable future!"
3074,jeffmcaffer@gmail.com,2004-06-08T16:11:21Z,18,0,"The avenues available to regular Java programs are available in Eclipse.  In a

What I was trying to say earlier was that either you have components/modules or

Those are the limitations I think for most people requesting this
I see a disconnect -- doing what I'm asking is not a ""regular Java-land
facility"" scenario.  Eclipse is an RCP *framework* -- it's not quite the same as
running the framework hosted app by itself from the command line.  Eclipse, in
my opinion, needs to be more flexible about allowing plug-ins to load classes
from other places on the filesystem.
I'd hate to see this become a philisophical discussion.  A lot of solid,
real-world scenarios have been raised in these comments about cases where this

3074,angben@comcast.net,2004-06-09T03:31:55Z,22,0,"> Question:  If you were not using Eclipse, how would
> you get access to these third party jars that are
I would think most likely by either specifying them on the classpath of the VM
at startup time, installing them in the ""ext"" portion of the VM, or using one's
own class loader.  I realize that all of these options are probably available
with Eclipse, but I don't think they map well to what I thought this RFE was
Eclipse is a ""multi-app"" (""plugins"") RCP framework, however, so I don't see
using the VM classpath as appropriate, putting things in the ""ext"" part of the
VM also seems inappropriate, and I'm still looking into how I could hook things
The rest of your questions raise interesting issues, which of course have no
universal, easy answers, but let me take a stab at some context:
> Who installed p.jar? (and when relative to installing P)
Assume p.jar pre-existed on the filesystem before P was installed, similar to
say a p.jar installed as an ""ext"" extension to the VM.
> How do you know that code in p.jar on your disk matches the
The same way you know that the API of the VM or an extension installed in ""ext""
matches the expectations of P 1.2.4.  Ie. assume we don't expect Eclipse to
Let's say the update manager.  p.jar is updated external to Eclipse.
> Who chooses $someplace$ and who sets the value?
Perhaps definable within the plugin.xml (for a fairly static environment), an
environment variable, or dynamically at plug-in start-up (for a more dynamic
> How does this play at development time (both for P and those who depend on P)
I believe Eclipse already allows a means for external JARs to be made available
at compilation time.  It's the runtime that seems more limited.
> How does this play at build time (is p.jar built by us?  Where is the source?
Is it available for others to compile against?)
Let's say that p.jar is not built by Eclipse, the source is not available, and
it is avaible (as .classes) for others to compile against.
> More generally, what are the possible external visibilities of the code in p.jar?
Unlimited.  p.jar exists as an entity outside the control of Eclipse.  Eclipse
gives up being the center of the universe as far as p.jar is concerned.

3074,christophe.avare@free.fr,2004-06-09T16:51:23Z,24,0,Thanks everybody for your answers, as my problem (at least) is solved.
The lastest trends in the dicussion are of great interest because they are
basically related to the effort that should be made to make Eclipse as pervasive
While all this discussion must be moved at some point into another more
appropriate place, i bet that people interested in this topic have a better
understanding of some issues to develop some ideas:
From the very beginning the classpath mechanism have been far from satisfactory,
The Eclipse plugin based framework is of great interest as a centralizing
mechanism: we can compare its advantages to the assembly concept for .NET which
is a huge improvement over the so-called DL-Hell.
But the outside world is both hostile and not very responsive to change, so
making the Eclipse a success leads to compromises, some of them being exposed in
While eradicating diversity in the distribution of Java components or
applications may require a lot of energy and time, it may be possible to make
the platform more attractive by considering a new project aimed at converting en
masse all the well known librairies used by the Java Community.
Consider the potential boost to the Eclipse community if all the Java librairies
from Apache and other famous Open Source be available as plugins from a central
I'm sure that all the legal issues can be overcomed and the community is ready

column1: From what I remember we crashed somehow (possibly by my own doing, not the platform's),
and when we restarted there was a problem.  DJ, do you remember more details?

column2: I believe that the scenerio was that a full_save on exit was interrupted (process
killed?) and never completed. This left an empty file where we were writing since
the stream was never closed. When the workspace is restored, the restore code
tries to read an int to get the version number for the reader and it fails with an
EOFException which is wrapped in a ResourceException. See SaveManager.restoreTree
for details. This is also applicable to restoring markers (MarkerManager.restoreFromSave)

column1: 3076,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2001-11-20T22:56:48Z,2,0,This is a really tricky area.  It stems from the fact that the Eclipse
workspace is always case-sensitive, but the file-system may not be.  We have
been unable to come up with a good solution for this that does not damage
performance (I.e., we don't want to be scanning for case variants for operations
that need to be quick, such as IResource#exists and IContainer#findMember).
What we've decided to try is this: we've introduced a new status code that
indicates a local operation has failed due to the unexpected existence of a case
So, in the case of this PR, IFolder#create will fail with the following status
This will allow the UI to handle this case gracefully.  In the case of import,
presumably this means it will ignore the failure and continue with the import.
Moving to the UI team for consideration and implementation.  Let us know if this
3076,Kevin_Haaland@ca.ibm.com,2001-11-22T02:03:57Z,3,0,Core has partial support for handling this that does not require upstream
3076,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2001-11-22T15:58:10Z,4,0,"I'm not sure what you mean by that...  I'm not sure what partial support you
are referring to.  We can't blindly overwrite resources on disk that happen to
be case variants of what the client is trying to create.  The method spec states
it will fail if a resource already exists on disk... the change we made just
tries to give the caller more information so they know how to deal with the
3076,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2002-01-04T18:29:49Z,5,0,"Created core RFC 0001 describing how core handles this case.  This RFC has now
been through comments and voting.  Link to RFC is:
Moving back to UI for handling the import case described by this PR."
3076,lynne_kues@us.ibm.com,2002-01-17T23:06:30Z,6,0,"I'm a bit confused about why Import should be handled differently than copy,
move, and create when a collision occurs.  Currently (20020115 build) when you
attempt to copy, move, or create and a name collision occurs, an error message
is displayed and the operation is aborted.  Why should import silently continue
when these other operations don't?  And even if we attempt to continue, I don't
think we should do it silently (i.e., it should be left up to the user to decide
what to do).  Why not just leave the behavior as is?  This is consistent with
the rest of the workbench operations."
3076,lynne_kues@us.ibm.com,2002-01-28T21:43:48Z,7,0,"First of all, the CaseInvariant exception is not thrown on Linux and the import
operation works (i.e., resources with the same name but different cases are
On WIN, if the CaseInvariant error occurs, import will still continue - just
those files with the conflict will not be imported (and an error message at the
end of the operation details this - though not as nicely as it could).
Let's say I wanted to try to ""silently handle"" it on Windows, I would have to do
something weird to allow the operation to work (e.g., rename the resource folder
I am unable to import to match the name of the resource folder it conflicts
with so that the CaseInvariant error doesn't occur).  This doesn't seem like the
right answer.  Or maybe when JA says ""silently handle"" he means don't show the
error message at the end.  This isn't very user-friendly either (i.e., if you're
doing a large import you may not realize some files didn't get imported due to a
So all I am going to try to do is improve the current error message.  Currently
if you run into a folder conflict for a particular file, you get the following
A resource exists with a different case <target folder name>.""
Unable to import <source file>: A resource exists with a different case <target

column1: 3078,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2001-11-05T16:19:31Z,2,0,Current behaviour is that it fails, saying folder ""fred"" does not exist.  Core
behaviour is working as designed.  Core interprets java.io.File.separatorChar as
Moving PR to UI.  They could be slightly nicer to the user by checking this
value as the user types.  They could either search for File.separatorChar, or
call IWorkspace#validateName on the exact text entered in the box.  UI currently
calls IWorkspace#validatePath, which splits the passed path into segments (in
this case ""fred"" and ""bob"" get separated), then validates each name."

3083,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2001-10-25T21:55:52Z,3,0,"Fixed.  The solution was to avoid calling PluginDescriptor.isPluginActivated()
from the sync block of the plugin class loader, in cases where activation is in
Also added comments in Plugin constructor and startup(), strongly suggesting
that sync blocks and other thread locking be avoided during plugin constructors
and startup() methods.  Since there is one monitor already acquired in the
plugin descriptor, it would only take one more monitor from client code to
create a deadlock.  We believe this is unavoidable...

3084,jeffmcaffer@gmail.com,2001-10-11T02:49:10Z,0,0,"The ant.jar included with the antsupport plugin does NOT include the standard Ant optional tasks.
As a result, these tasks are not available to Ant support plugin users.

column2: The immediate problem is easy to fix.  Include the require jar(s) in the Ant support plugin.
This does not however solve the class lookup problem.  for example, the Junit task will
want to find various junit classes from the junit.jar (supplied separately).  The ant support
plugin has some rudimentary support for registering various classes in an extension point
and then tasks can indirect off the extension to load the actual class without requiring the
supplying plugin to be a prereq of the ant plugin.  Unfortunatlye, this requires changes to
I don;t know the real answer right now.  I suspect that for 1.0 the best we can do is solve
this with the other third party jar problems and let people spec the jars in the
java.exe -classpath arg (currently we drop that classpath and construct our own based on the
plugin.xmls).  This is not a great solution but it gets us running in the near term.

3089,klicnik@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:49:15Z,0,0,"PluginDescriptor.gerResourceBundle(Locate) is not fragment-aware (only looks inside the

column2: plugin directory). Consequently, the NL versions of the plugin.properties files cannot be
Shouldn't getResourceBundle() use the same classpath as the normal plugin class loader?
Actually it is unclear why we need a different class loader at all?  the current code limits us to
finding resource bundles only in the install dir of the plugin.  Bundles in jars and in library
I think where we are right now is a statement of how we evolved. The code predates fragments
and was there so workbench could get at translated plugin.properties, or any other resource
bundle that was NOT part of the actual code .jar. None of our plugins specify <library name=""./""/>
so the extra class loader was just a cheap way (in terms of coding) of getting the plugin.properties
found and loaded. So the question is, what are the correct semantics to support? Some possible

column3: use extra loader, make its classpath include plugin dir, and all detected fragment dirs. This

column4: would be ""morally equivalent"" to the current support. One would place plugin.properties
files in the root of the plugin or fragment directory

column3: defer to the plugin loader to do the loading. This would require all plugins to specify

column4: <library name=""./""/> so the default plugin.properties are found.

column3: use extra loader as today, but parent it using the plugin loader (rather than null).

column4: This would preserve current behavior (ie. not have the downside of (2)), but if we fail
would then do the regular search (fragment aware). The fragments would have a choice
of specifying <library name=""./""/> and exposing the property file, or could just
bundle it at a root of one of the supplied jars.

column2: Would need the <library name=""./""/> handling fixed (as file:, not jar:).
I think I would vote for (3) ...
On second thought, (3) would cause the parent loader to be searched first before going to the
base plugin directory, so this may not be what we want. So

column3: use extra loader, its classpath set to plugin directory + classpath of plugin loader

column2: Have tried with option (3) as the fix and things seem to work.
Looking at the trace, option (3) causes the classloaders for ALL plugins that contribute to the UI to be created
as part of the workbench startup. This is because the workbench is looking for the plugin.properties strings
and option (3) causes the plugin loaders to be created. This may be OK (not a heavy operation) but some of the
plugin loaders may never be actually used beyond this point. Also, when searching for the bundles, option (3)
causes the prereq loader trees to be searched (search is guaranteed to fail for plugin.properties bundles)
Have done a few unscientific measurements using option (3) [the simplest fix]. All are done using the following configuration:

column3: launching self-hosted eclipse, base drop + example plugins
running with -debug, but only runtime tracing enabled (to get timings)
So it would appear the startup cost of creating all the loaders that contrinuted UI elements, PLUS performing
longer lookup searches for the plugin.properties bundles is about 1 second on my slow machine.
This is with the base drop plus examples. In a large configuration we are likely to have 2-5 times as many plugins
contributing to the UI so we would see corresponding increase in startup times.

column2: Option (4) comes out marginally slower than current support ... basically not paying the performance cost of option (3).
The conclusion is that the actual extra cost is not from creation of the loaders, but rather from the unnecessary
searching down the prerequisite tree (always guaranteed to fail for the bundle, is multipled by Java locale-based
Have created ""1GHOOPO: ITPCORE:WINNT - translated plugin.properties (R1.0 support)"" to track the R1.0 partial fix.
Using option (4) as the fix. Keeping this PR open to make sure we revisit this in the 2.0 stream."

3095,klicnik@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:49:21Z,0,0,The current fragment support does not allow strings in the fragment.xml to be isolated and translated. In particular, this is a problem for

column2: any contributed extensions (but also for extension point names/ etc that appear in PDE UI).
The problem is that we only support a single plugin.properties, and information contributed by fragments is looked up in the
plugin.properties bundle. Any one given fragment could play the NL game and supply plugin.properties containing base strings plus
strings for itself, but this would miss other fragments.
We need a mechanism that allows a fragment to contribute strings that logically augment the plugin.properties, without creating
conflicts with the base plugin, or other fragments for that plugin (ie. sort-of-a ""fragmented"" bundle). Until we have a solution,
fragments are really not usable to contribute extensions that need to be NL-enabled.
Related PR: 1GHH215: ITPCORE:WINNT - translated plugin.properties cannot be contributed by fragments"

fragment directories to be communicated from the plugin descriptor.

column1: Unable to read authorization database: c:\workspaces\eclipse\.metadata\.keyring.

column2: Were you switching between J9 and JDK or something like this?  There is a fundamental problem with
the J9 random number generator not generating the same sequence of numbers as the JDK version.
As a result, the decryption of the keyring fails if the keyring was written with a different class lib.
I switch back and forth between JDK and J9 all the time.
This is a known problem.  For now we can't do anything about it since it is actually a JCL problem that
cannot be fixed (they are not allowed to look at the Sun implementation to duplicate the sequence).
The workaround is to delete the .keyring file when you change between VMs.  In the furture we will
probably have our own random implementation.
I have written an implementation of the SHA pseudo-random number generator (SHAPRNG).
Despite the fancy name and overwhelming acronym, the implementation is trivial (two short methods).
We can use this to maintain consistency across class libraries.  J9 doesn't seem to be available in
current builds, so I'm waiting until it's possible to test the implementation.  We should also auto-delete
the keyring file if there was a load failure, otherwise the user will have to delete it manually when we switch
See also 1GLBU8U: ITPCORE:WINNT - UTFDataFormatException opening a 202a workspace with 203
Different stack trace, but also likely due to the corrupted cipher stream."

Using the latest IBM JDK (1.3.0 Service Release 9a cn130-20010609) from Hursley fails. You can't bring up the
workbench if there is a space somewhere in the path. For example, if Eclipse is in a directory
like  ""c:\some path with a space\eclipse"" it won't come up.
A little bit of debugging shows that in Main.getBootPath(String) this statement:
Returns a url with the spaces turned into ""%20"". For example, the above path
It then can't find anything because ""%20"" is not treated as a space but as
characters in the path and it can't find that path.
The same thing happens in InternalBootLoader.getInstallURL().
A workaround for now is to use the option:
This then works and you can bring up Eclipse.

If a file cannot even be *read*, this of course causes all kinds of Eclipse erorrs (build problems).

After the problem is fixed, say, with manipulations outside of Eclipse, a manual ""refresh"" on that particular file does not remove the errors. Eclipse simply refuses to try building again. The user says: ""Please reconsider this file."", Eclipse says: ""Nay, I won't do that.""
The only known workaround is a ""clean"" (i.e., rebuild) the entire project.
So, by merging the writeable issue with the readable issue, this bug has become a more serious issue than it had been for several years.
The original ""I cannot write the file"" has been alleviated for most practical uses, by:
> Editors now detect changes in read-only status by themselves.
But the builders don't detect changes in readable status, so, as far as that is concerned, we are back to where this bug was 2001."

3111,klicnik@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:49:37Z,0,0,"Our classloader mechanisms have changed to resolve platform: URLs prior to constructing the loader (for improved performance).

column2: As a side-effect, this causes the caching support built into the ""platform:"" support for remotely installed plugins to be
bypassed. Need to fix for 2.0 if we want to enable running-from-server.
We should probably use an approach that
* passes the classpath as platform: URLs to PluginClassLoader and PlatformClassLoader
* on first use of loader, poof up the classpath doing asLocalURL() and super.addURL(...)
This will trigger caching for remote jars, but delay this to first use (rather than loader construction). The current code does resolve() prior

column1: 3112,dj.houghton@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:49:38Z,0,0,"When using the ""ant"" task to execute another Ant script, if there are Eclipse tasks in this Ant script, then I get an error saying that:
BuildException: D:\Eclipse_self-hosting\0.132\eclipse\workspace\Ant-Task-Tests\InitTemplate.xml:6: Could not create task of type: initTemplate. Common solutions are to use taskdef to declare""
1. Here is the first Ant script:
2. Here is the second Ant script that is called: (""initTemplate"" is a PDE Ant task.)
3. Run the first script: you get the error.
The EclipseAnt class, which is the one called for the ""ant"" task, creates a ""Project"" project while initializing itself. It sets the properties of the calling project to this new project.
That means that if you have put somewhere ""initTemplate"" in the first Ant script, then it works.
Try the following example that works:
When the EclipseProject is created for this script, the taskdef for ""initTemplate"" is added to the taskdef list of the project. (cf. EclipseProject#createTask). Therefore,
when the ""ant"" task creates a ""Project"" project and sets the properties of the calling project to this project, the definition of ""initTemplate"" is passed, and there is no error.
** So the problem comes from the fact that when creating a task, an EclipseProject knows that it has to look into the AntPlugin task extensions list to find the class that
** corresponds to a given task name, but a basic Apache Project does not know how to do that.
** Or, the ""ant"" task creates an Apache Project.

column2: Bug Fixed. Needs reviewing and releasing.

3115,jeem@moths.ca,2002-04-22T19:40:59Z,3,0,Proposal: add the following method to IProjectDescriptor:
* Returns a URL for the file at the given plug-in relative path. The file
* is looked for in the plug-in and any of its fragments. The
* translate parameter controls whether the file should be
* Returns null if the URL could not be computed or created.
* Unlike Plugin.find, this method does not require the plug-in
* be activated; it looks in fragments; and it can handle locale-specific
* @param filePath a plug-in relative path of a file in the plug-in
*   installation location, or in one of its fragments
* @param translated true if the file may be translated and
*    should also be sought in locale-specific subdirectories, and
* false if this file would never be translated or exist
* @return a URL for the given path or null
public URL find(IPath filePath, boolean translated);
3115,debbie_wilson@ca.ibm.com,2002-04-30T15:08:47Z,4,0,This functionality has been added to IPluginDescriptor (and PluginDescriptor
internally).  These new find methods will not cause the plugin to be
activated.  Note that the find methods in Plugin have now been changed to use
The URL returned from find (in Plugin/IPluginDescriptor/PluginDescriptor) is no
longer a platform URL but a 'real' URL that does not need to be processed
through Platform.resolve().  Processing through Platform.resolve() will just
cause the same URL to be returned.
The decision to return non-platform URLs was made because in the Plugin.find
code, a non-platform URL was returned if the thing being looked for was in a
fragment directory and a platform URL was returned if it was found in a plugin
directory.  For consistency, non-platform URLs will be returned in all cases.
Fragments do not currently support platform URLs.
Another minor change - this code would look in the option root directory but
not in the fragment or plugin root directory.  Now, if a $<option>$ is
specified, the option root directory will not be searched but the root of the
plugin and any fragments will.  For example:  if you were looking for
$nl$/plugin.properties and your default locale was en_CA the old code would
The new code will search the following directories:
This is now consistent with where we search for jar and system library files.
There is a glitch in the current support ... Jeff has a core PR to address
this in 2.0 ... 1GHOZI1: ITPCORE:WINNT - Strings contributed by
We can get away with this in 1.0 the way we use fragments for nl, because
the fragment.xml strings are not really used in our UI. Would be a problem
if the fragment contributed an extension, but this is a low-probability
scenario at this point. Need to fix in 2.0. A partial solution would be to
add new keys to the plugin.properties nl variant, but this does not allow
adding a default (from nl point of view) version of the string (ref. your
prior question about the default plugin.properties).
Follow up dumb: How do you externalize the plugin name of the
Good question ... had to look at the code to see how things got loaded.
If you include plugin.properties directly in the fragment directory it is
never looked at. If you include it in the root of the jar contributed by
the fragment then the plugin.properties in the base plugin wins.
So the answer is the base plugin always wins.
Is the fragment allowed to have a plugin.properties.
I realize it has the en, jp ones etc - but I was wondering if it had a
plugin.properties if thus would cause confusion as to
whether this one wins or the one in the main plugin

Last Friday, when I was trying to view source for the jre classes (not
being able to set JRE_SRC at the time), I tried a bunch of things which
included putting a symlink to /home in my project directory.
When I removed the project I was testing with, it asked me if I wanted to
remove the files in the project directory (you can probably guess what's coming
next).  It descended into my home directory and started to remove all of
the files it could that I owned (it removed my cvs repository among other
things).  Luckily, this is a fairly new installation and I didn't have
much in /home that I couldn't restore!
To prevent this behavior, I would suggest using getCanonicalPath() on
each directory before descending into it, to verify that the current
directory is actually the candidate's parent.

3128,eclipse-bugs@rizzoweb.com,2003-02-14T14:57:53Z,15,0,"I think there are a few things that might be done to make this less traumatic
for the user if he happens to stumble upon an OOM error (which seem to be the
most common cause of workspace corruptions, based on the bug reports listed above).
1) Making shutdown as tight as possible, not requiring persisting of so much
critical data. I don't know the internals, but perhaps more of the info can be
persisted ""as you go"" instead of waiting for workbench shutdown. Possibly in the
background. The goal should be to get shutdown as small as possible, so VM
failure at that point is not so tragic.
2) A fallback to ""last known good"" configuration (as has been discussed in this
and other bugs) could be implemented in Eclipse startup. The process to recover
a workspace that has bad .tree and/or .snap files is pretty simple to fix
without losing a lot of data, but it should be built in as much as possible.
3) In lieu of the above, a little more helpful logging pointing to the exact
file(s) that are corrupt is needed, as well as some prominent documentation
about how to recover from a corrupt workspace. It should not be so difficult for
users to learn what to do to get back to work."

3128,dj.houghton@ca.ibm.com,2003-03-12T20:20:16Z,18,0,"The problem is that the master table is saved in the finally block of
So this looks like what is happening:
- start saving workspace tree (1.tree is ok and on disk, we are saving 2.tree)
- get an exception saving 2.tree so this file is now only half there
- writes master table which has reference to 2.tree
So on startup we read the master table, it tells us to read 2.tree and then we
We need to refactor the code so if we have a failure when saving, we do not
delete any files. We should ensure that all the old files are there so we can
at least try to use them to bring the platform up.
Unfortuanatly too risky to make changes in this area for 2.1.

3128,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2003-04-21T14:37:54Z,21,0,"*** Bug 36626 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***"
Cleanup code has been moved out of the finally block.  This means cleanup of
unused files will not happen on abormal save termination, so the valid tree file
will not be deleted.  Also moved the code to commit the master table immediately
after writing the tree, otherwise an error between those operations would result
in a master table pointing to the wrong tree.
Here is the revised timeline from DJ's comment:
- start saving workspace tree (1.tree is ok and on disk, we are saving 2.tree)
- get an exception saving 2.tree so this file is now only half there
Now, the master table still has a reference to 1.tree, and we have 1.tree and
2.tree on disk.  On next startup, 1.tree will be read, and on next shutdown,
2.tree will be overwritten with the next valid save state.

column2: This could be a concurrency problem.  Since the tree is not locked during visitor traversal,
another thread could delete a container between the existence check in Container#members()
and ElementTree#getChildren(), causing the above exception.
Minimally we should be catching the IllegalArgumentException thrown by the tree layer
and throwing a core exception.  At least then a message would get back to the user saying
Resource /foo/... does not exist"", and they would know to redo the operation they were trying."

column1: 3129,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2001-11-15T17:18:06Z,2,0,Added some protective code to make it safe during concurrent access. Since this
method can be called from many places, some of which don't expect exceptions, I
just return an empty set of children if the resource has been replaced
concurrently during the call. This way visitors won't fail unneccesarily.
Tested and released into HEAD.  No readme or buildnotes needed."

column1: 3132,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2001-10-30T17:40:02Z,2,0,Fixed.  I now only report the error once per session.  On all subsequent build
attempts during that session, a single line message is printed to the log
indicating what went wrong, and no exception is thrown.
I think the error is sufficiently severe that the user should be notified... it
means that the project is probably no longer working as expected.  However, it
is annoying if this message continues to interrupt the user.  My fix is a
3132,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2001-10-30T22:48:32Z,3,0,"I wasn't completely satisfied with the fix so I made some more changes.
Basically the builder persistent info for the old builder would have hung around
forever, and it would have maintained a reference to an old tree.  I now create
a ""fake"" builder to replace the builder that couldn't be instantiated.  As far
as the core is concerned, this builder looks and acts like a normal builder so
no special code is required.  However, when this fake builder is first run, it
throws an exception, and then silently logs exceptions for all future build
attempts.  This made the code much cleaner."

column2: Sets the local file system location for the described project. If null is specified, the default location

column1: is used. Setting the location on a description for a project which already exists has no effect; the
new project location is ignored when the description is set on the already existing project. This
method is intended for use on descriptions for new projects or for destination projects for copy

column2: When starting up the eclipse workspace BootLoader.run accepts a filename of a property file.
The property file defines the location of plugins to be found by the plugin loader.
The solution to pass arguments in a file is not very elegant. At least the JavaDoc would have to describe the
file format / content precicly, which it doesn't at all.
Wouldn't it be possible to pass in the plugin paths as an array of URLs?
The URL points to the plugin.XML, which defines the plugin ID.
Another URL could describe the default location.

column1: We have someone here who is moving a large number of projects from VAME to
Eclipse. We're talking about over 150 projects which are loaded into the
workspace at one time. Note that this is actually a normal configuration for
the type of work this person does. Having moved these projects, we are now
seeing a performance issue we don't quite understand.
Every time a file is changed, a progress dialog appears with an updating
message which says ""Reading resource change information"" followed by the
names of all the projects in the workspace. This dialog lasts about 20-30
seconds. Now if we were changing java source and there were numerous
interrelated projects I could understand, but that does not appear to be the
For example, we created a brand new java project which has no references to
any of the other 150+ projects (nor do the other projects reference this new
one). We then created an .xml file in this project and opened it in an
editor. Everytime we save the .xml file, we see the progress dialog racing
through all the other projects in the workspace. Why is this? None of those
projects should be affected by this project, and certainly not by a change
The ""Reading resource change information"" message indicates the Java
builder is asking the platform for the delta computations.
When the build button is pressed, all Java projects are traversed to see
if they need to be rebuild based on the changes in them and the changes in
their prerequisites. Note that a change inside a resource file on the
classpath still need the Java builder to copy it into the binary output

column2: A massive improvement here could be accomplished as follows:

column3: - find out the set of projects that have changed
- for each builder, if any of its ""interesting projects"" have changed, invoke builder

column2: This would mean we don't even have to invoke the builder if we know it won't

column1: 3137,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2001-10-15T16:48:58Z,1,0,"Fixed.  Summary of changes (all in BuildManager and ResourceDeltaFactory:
- not eagerly opening the tree for builds (means less tree layers)
- Before invoking a builder, compute dtree delta since last build and see if
there are any changes to project this builder cares about.  If not, the builder
- When builder requests a delta, see if that project has changed (by looking at
dtree delta computed above), and return an empty delta if not changed (saves
- Cache the last ResourceDelta requested by a builder.  If the old and new trees
haven't changed since last request, just return the cached copy.  The cache
expires at the end of any build cycle to avoid holding onto large garbage

column2: there exists dir 'a' and a subdir 'Copy Of s'
i call findMember(""Copy of s"") on a and get null (note the different case in 'Of')
ok, it doesn't exist so i can create it - but then i get an exception saying that it does exist already.
(actually i call IResource::copy to create the new resource)
i think, it should either be 'ignore case everywhere in resource names' or 'never ignore case'.
in the ui land - i have no way to tell that the copy call will fail.
i check if the resource exists - and it supposedly doesn't.
The problem is that Eclipse is always case-sensitive, and your filesystem isn't.  It's really
difficult to be consistent here, considering we support case-sensitive and insensitive filesystems.
You can check the return status from the copy call to see why it failed... It seems acceptable
to allow the user to try it, and then the error message should explain why it failed.
then i think findMember should be filesystem-aware.
or core should provide another, filesystem-aware, routine to verify the file name
another example is: 1GEUO7L: ITPJUI:ALL - magic 'aux' name not handled by refactoring"

column1: 3140,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2001-11-20T23:03:46Z,2,0,This is a really tricky area.  We have been unable to come up with a good
solution for this that does not damage performance (I.e., we don't want to be
scanning for case variants for operations that need to be quick, such as
What we've decided to try is this: we've introduced a new status code that
indicates a local operation has failed due to the unexpected existence of a case
So, create, copy and move calls will continue to fail when a case variant is
detected, but the following status code will be in the exception:
This will allow clients to handle the case more consistently and gracefully.  We
know it's not ideal, because you can't quickly test for this as the user types a
name.  My reasoning is that this case is rare enough that this solution will be
acceptable.  The user will just get a message saying a conflicting file has been
found, and they'll quickly understand how they can work around it.
Adam, please give us some feedback if this approach does not work for you."

3153,klicnik@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:50:22Z,0,0,"Need to add an ability to force a user to accept (or reject) a license agreement prior to downloading and installing

column2: A simple approach for handling this could be to define a convention where the license agreement is placed in a well-known
file (eg. license.txt) or a well-known key in install.properties. If this file/ key is detected, its content is displayed in a dialog
with Accept (allow download and install) and Reject (abort operation) buttons. Note, the mechanism needs to support NL
translations, and character encoding (using well known key in install properties make this a simpler implementation, although
given the complexity + size of some license agreements it may not be the most convenient place)."

column1: 3153,klicnik@ca.ibm.com,2002-01-22T17:55:50Z,1,0,"No longer applicable. The R1.0 update support is withdrawn in 2.0."
Re: Multiple users sharing an Eclipse install on Linux
Thanks Vlad, that's good news.  I believe it is reasonable to have software
updates installable only by someone with root authority.  Theoretically it
should be possible to have Help > Software Update work, but prompt the user for
the root password for proper authentication.  I've seen this done when you use
RPM and aren't logged in as root.
> Steve, ability to share a single install was one of the base design points
> of Eclipse (this is one place you can say we've learned from our prior
> experiences ;-) ). We have taken great care to ensure plugins don't rely on
> having write access to the installation tree. In fact we have made it hard
> for a plugin to know where exactly it is installed (all normal access is
> through URLs using an eclipse protocol that does the magic mapping). So as
> long as you launch the shared Eclipse with each user having their own
> writeable workbench (tool state and actual resources) all should be well
> There may be cases where a plugin was written to rely on accessing its
> directory. We do not make it easy to program this way, so this scenario
> will be a case of someone consciously going out and programming around the
> APIs we provide (I am mentioning this only because there are several
> discussion threads in the newsgroup with questions along these lines).
> These plugins would fail in your configuration.
> The only other thing I can think of is that the Help> Software Update
> function will be disabled for your users (cannot install/ update into
> shared r/o tree). Updates to the shared install would need to be done by a
> user with r/w access doing the update (using native installer or the update

A) What encoding should be used for install.xml?

column3: You should use encoding=""UTF-8"" just like for plugin.xml files. The header entry in the file should be
We have tested using DBCS characters in the display fields, specifically the label= attribute on the various
tags. The DBCS characters can be placed directly in the install.xml file, or the strings can first be
separated into install_<locale>.properties and then translated as a regular Java properties file.
If separated, the install_<locale>.properties files need to be exposed on the server. They appear
as peer files to install.xml. See the online documentation for details ... Help> Help Contents, select
Platform Plug-In Developer Guide > Reference> Other Reference Information> Platform Installation
and Update, section Translating Packaging Information."

3169,klicnik@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:50:38Z,0,0,"When an installation (unzip) has failed, the undo code will remove every file defined in the jar's
install.xml and inside the jar.   This means that if a plugin was previously installed by another
component, and a new component is being installed containing the same plugin, and the installation
failed, the undo code will remove that plugin.
The undo code will need to be smart enough to remove what's actually unzipped, OR, we do all the
unzip in a staging area and move things to the actual location when everything's good (there's still
the chance of failure during the move, though).
3169,klicnik@ca.ibm.com,2002-01-22T18:07:51Z,2,0,No longer applicable. The R1.0 update support is withdrawn in 2.0."
3170,klicnik@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T02:50:39Z,0,0,"Fix for 1GDTX3J is incomplete - if eclipse crashes during unzipping a plugin, the only pending delete
item is the plugin itself, so the plugin gets cleaned up during platform startup, but the component
itself is not removed as it was installed successfully in a previous operation.
The installPending and installConfirmed calls need to be made on a parcel basis.
One way to implement this is to define a new operation on the parcel - it registers everything that is
to be unzipped, and at the end of all the unzip operation, define another operation to confirm that
How about, a new operation that registers everything that is to be unzipped, and as the component
and plugins are unzipped, the doUnzip code confirms what has been unzipped.   This way we can
keep the installConfirmed calls in doUnzip( ) and undoUnzip( )."

3187,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2002-03-22T19:08:48Z,3,0,"Unfortunately it's really difficult to improve this.  I don't know if a given
builder has actual work to do until all the builders that preceed it in the
build spec have run.  A project might have no work to do at the start of the
build cycle, but might have plenty of work to do after one of its prerequisite
There are some cases where this could be improved, but it's too much up front
effort for little reward.  After all, there are still the text progress messages
so the user still gets feedback that work is being done."

3328,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2001-11-14T17:31:16Z,3,0,This is one of those cases where the history store can barf and be left in an
inconsistent state.  Chain of events I observed:
- attempt to write to history store.  IOException due to lack of disk space
- The IOException leaves the indexed store in an inconsistent state
- attempt to set file contents.  Exception
- User is notified of that file is out of sync with filesystem (is this the UI
just guessing because core threw an exception??).
- Attempt to shutdown.  The fact that the IndexedStore is broken causes a
failure during shutdown... this aborts shutdown in the middle and leaves the
tree file in a half-written state
- The workspace is now toast.  Since the tree is corrupted, there is no way to

disk space, shutdown is never going to go well.  Closing for now.  Perhaps we
could revist serialization after 2.0 to see if there are any more opportunities

3328,dj.houghton@ca.ibm.com,2003-03-05T23:43:27Z,11,0,"Re-opening for investigation of the missing states problem."
3328,eclipse@abstratt.com,2003-03-06T15:13:10Z,12,0,"We can have so two situations where an out-of-disk-space IOException may arise
when saving a file (IFile#setContents) in a full (or near to full) disk.
1) when the currently saved state of the file is copied to the local history
(may fail expanding the index, or writing the contents) - no exceptions will be
raised, only logged, and the saving process will go on - this is good;
2) when the current contents in the editor will replace the existing ones. This
may not fail because the new content length can be smaller than the saved one.
When ""1"" happens, data loss shouldn't occur - only new states could not be
added. I could reproduce a case where the last state was lost - and this is a
When ""2"" happens, a proper exception is thrown by IFile#setContents to clients.
The problem Knut faced (previous state restoration) is a result of the
mishandling of the exception by AbstractTextEditor (which allows the user to
load the corrupted state from disk).
Unfortunately, according to bug 32765 comment 1, AbstractTextEditor blinded
handling of CoreExceptions is not going to be fixed.

3328,daniel_megert@ch.ibm.com,2010-08-02T10:35:40Z,17,0,"This is not fixed (3.6 and N20100729-2000): org.eclipse.core.resources.IFile.setContents(InputStream, boolean, boolean, IProgressMonitor) throws an exception to report the 'out of disk' condition but at that time it has already already corrupted the file (file is empty).

Note that the editor correctly tells this to the user but as just said, the file is already gone at that point, which in my opinion should not happen: the API should not touch/corrupt the file if there's not enough space.

To make things worse, the history mechanism does not report the CoreException and just logs an error if it cannot save itself due to out of disk space.
