3551,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2001-11-13T20:24:25Z,4,0,"I don't see the special case here.  The following are equivalent from core's
- modify a file in an internal eclipse editor, save
- modify in external editor, save, refresh local
Both of these sequences yield a delta describing that the file has changed.  In
neither case has a marker been changed.
Core doesn't interpret the values of marker attributes.  I think what you're
suggesting is that core should, for every changed file, walk over the markers
for that file and update the line and character position attributes.  Core
doesn't have the knowledge or the responsibility to do this.  We can't infer
what lines have been modified in the file, and so can't update marker attributes
accordingly.  Even if we could, it would be out of place for Core to modify the
attributes of markers it didn't create.
I don't think anything can be done here.
3551,dirk_baeumer@ch.ibm.com,2001-11-14T07:47:41Z,5,0,I agree that Core can't update the markers if we change the file using an
external editor. But the problem also shows up if we change a file using the
core infrastructure directly. Consider the followingh case:
Java Core changes a file using JDOM. Doing so invalidates all markers since
marker updating is currently done by the text infrastructure which lives in the
Since Core introduces the concept of Markers and Files, Core should be
responsible to keep them in sync when changing the file or marker is done
through the Core infrastructure. Otherwise everybody who is using Core files is
in the business to update markers when he changes the content of a file.
I already discussed this issue with Jeem and he agreed that this is core
3551,jeem@moths.ca,2001-11-19T16:03:02Z,6,0,"Core's notion of markers includes standard attributes for a
character range (IMarker.CHAR_START and CHAR_END) and a line number
(LINE_NUMBER). Core could provide the essential infrastructure for
adjusting markers when the marked file is changed by a client that
can describe how the file's contents were edited. The onus would be
entirely on the client to request that markers for a resource
be updated, and provide the information that allows such adjustments
The proposed core infrastructure is an operation that adjusts markers
on a particular file resource according to a client-supplied edit
description capable of describing a batch of non-overlapping changes.
E.g., an edit description might contain
2. replace character range [200,300) with 0 characters (i.e., a deletion)
3. replace character range [400,400) with 20 characters (i.e., an insertion)
The source ranges are in terms of the original contents of the file, and
can be applied in any order. This info is sufficient to determine whether
a marker at a given character range should be moved, expanded/truncated,
or deleted outright. Although this calculation is straightforward and could
be done by any client that edits a file, having the operation in core
would make it simpler for all clients to get this common thing done right.
3551,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2001-11-19T17:31:40Z,7,0,Ah, this makes more sense.  I thought Dirk was implying Core could handle this
Is updating CHAR_START and CHAR_END sufficient, or is LINE_NUMBER needed as
well?  The character positions could be updated quickly given the information
Jeem describes, but updating the line numbers is trickier.  If the characters
from 200->400 have been deleted, core can't compute how many line separators
have been removed, and so cannot update the LINE_NUMBER correctly."
3551,jeem@moths.ca,2001-11-21T19:50:38Z,8,0,"I believe that line numbers are less useful to clients at this
stage. I suggest focussing on updating character positions, for
which there are bona fide existing clients.
3551,kai-uwe_maetzel@ch.ibm.com,2001-11-28T16:06:34Z,9,0,Updating positions seems simple only at the first glance. Having user defined
marker types, it is also part of the marker type definition how the marker
positions are updated. Assume a marker at [100, 150. Now assume an insert at
100. What happens to the marker? Is the marker moved or expanded? Well, you
can't answer. It depends on the marker type. Even worse, the updating of marker
positions might depend on the concrete changes, e.g., what was the content of
the text that has been deleted. The list of these issues can grow rather long.
Bottom line is that the core can not define the semantics of marker position
updating but must be open for custom made solutions.
In addition, marker position updating is good to have. However, the problems
are the same for potentially any marker property.  "
3551,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2001-11-29T21:54:25Z,10,0,"I have added a draft RFC (0004) to the Core team web page.  Please review and
provide comments on the core mailing list.  Link location:
3551,john.arthorne@gmail.com,2002-09-24T22:05:58Z,13,0,"I assume this bug report can be closed, since a marker update mechanism has
since been added to the API of the org.eclipse.ui plugin?"
3551,dirk_baeumer@ch.ibm.com,2002-09-25T07:51:35Z,14,0,"John, can you please point me to the new API."

separate thread. They have to be executed in the UI thread

Possible soultion is to used a special progress monitor that reads the

column2: cancel an operation even if it is executed in the UI thread.
See: 1GEJ66W: ITPUI:WIN2000 - Need way to cancel an operation that
We already have changed the implementation so that a refactoring is

column1: cancelable during its precondition checking phase. It is not

column2: cancelable when we the actual code change takes place. In my opinion

column1: this is the right way to go anyway since:

column3: - the precondintion checking takes the longest amount of time.
- the actual change shouldn't be cancelable anyway since the

column1: program can end up in an inconsistent state. Furthermore it is not

column3: possible to generate an undo object for an canceled
- the user can undo the refactoring by activating undo.

column2: Waiting for comments from EG and AK.
Not fully true. Precondition checking is only cancelable when pressing

column1: Next on the first page. When pressing Finish the whole

column2: There are different solutions for that problem:
a.) we post every change to a document into the UI thread. This enables

column1: to run the operation in a different thread and makes it

column2: b.) the document / document provider or the listener fixes the problem.

column1: But then JFace Text is the only component that deals with

column2: c.) Java Core improves IBuffer in a way that it reports more fine

column1: grained changes. This would enable the document to keep markers

column2: for non changed text segements. If we do that, the Refactoring

column1: Core could use IBuffer from Java Core to do their text changes instead
3738,dirk_baeumer@ch.ibm.com,2002-01-22T13:33:15Z,2,0,There is not too much we can do since the refactoring infrastructure doesn't
know anything about the UI to post the changes into the UI thread. We can
implement a hack but IMO the text infrastructure should deal with the case that
documents can be changed from a different thread as well.
3738,erich_gamma@ch.ibm.com,2002-01-25T13:54:31Z,3,0,"Request to use the EventLoopProgressMonitor when the operation is executed in
the same thread was sent to the workbench team."
3738,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2002-05-14T18:24:26Z,4,0,"Doing work in the UI thread is not the right answer.
It would be better to change the text infrastructure to issue callbacks to
widgets in the UI thread, but allow modification of documents in a non-UI
EventLoopProgressMonitor may be an expedient workaround.  We did this for
editor saves.  However, it's not the right answer here either."
3738,nick_edgar@ca.ibm.com,2002-05-14T18:34:45Z,5,0,"Canceling a refactoring seems dangerous anyway.  Can it be done atomically?"
3738,dirk_baeumer@ch.ibm.com,2002-05-14T18:47:57Z,6,0,"No, it can't be done atomically. The idea was that we allow cancel as long as
we do precondition checking and only when we start to perform the changes we
would disable the cancel button when executed in a different thread."
3738,dirk_baeumer@ch.ibm.com,2002-05-14T19:57:13Z,7,0,"Nobody complaint so far thar refactoring isn't cancelable when pressing the
Finish button before the preview page has been reached. So I opt to do nothing

3939,unknown63@eclipse.org,2001-11-22T21:05:47Z,5,0,"The following method on IWorkbenchPage opens an editor on the given file
public IEditorPart openEditor(IFile input) throws PartInitException;
An appropriate editor for the input is determined using a multistep process.
- The workbench editor registry is consulted to determine if an editor
extension has been registered for the file type.  If so, an
instance of the editor extension is opened on the file.
- Next, the native operating system will be consulted to determine if a native
editor exists for the file type.  If so, a new process is started
and the native editor is opened on the file.
- If all else fails the file will be opened in a default text editor.

3970,matthew@mxtelecom.com,2004-05-06T12:12:56Z,27,0,"The inability to choose a specific line delimiter when creating files (and
checking them out of CVS) is a huge shortcoming for me; when running Eclipse on
Windows, my projects are often outside the workspace on a unix development box
running Samba.  In order to build the project and use commandline cvs tools
locally on the unix box from the working dir, ASCII files /must/ have LF
delimiters.  Even an integrated batch conversion tool would be better than
nothing, as currently the only quasi-solution is to run an external s/CRLF/LF/g
batch process whenever new files are introduced by Eclipse-on-Windows in the
filetree.  Which then breaks Eclipse's cvs diffs.  *Please* consider upgrading
This is a hideous hack, but it seems to provide a crass workaround for my
specific problem.  On looking at the source, it appears that Eclipse uses
System.getProperty(""line.separator"") for *all* line termination logic - both
for doing CVS diffs, creating new files, etc.  So to make Windows Eclipse
workspaces compatible with *nix commandline tools (e.g. when accessing a unix-
hosted workspace over samba), all one has to do is to override Eclipse's JVM's
line.separator System property to be just LF.  All my Windows tools which work
on the workspace are happy with UNIX line endings (e.g. javac, text editors),
with the possible exception of TortoiseCVS - which Eclipse obviously supplants
To override system properties for a JVM, one would typically pass in -
Dline.separator=<LF> at the commandline.  Apologies if there's a better way of
specifying properties for Eclipse's JVM than this; I couldn't see any
in 'Running Eclipse' in Help.  The problem arises in how to express LF (0x0a)
in the commandline - under the NT CMD and batch files I see no obvious way to
escape the 0x0a character, likewise in the Eclipse shortcut editing properties
dialog.  So instead I've used the win32 IShellLink Interface as wrapped by
Win32::Shortcut in Perl to manually insert the appropriate commandline args in
for my particular case. And this appears so far to work and solve all my line
termination problems.  Apologies if this is obvious to everyone else, or a
truly horrible way of passing in binary system properties :)"

that goes along with it and this bug probably won't be included, but I think
that many of the users would agree that this bug should be very high on the
priority list for the next release (3.0.1 or 3.1 or whatever)."

3970,Mike_Wilson@ca.ibm.com,2005-04-26T17:31:33Z,57,0,"First off, please try to avoid making derogatory comments about *anyone* (the developers or the other
posters). If this bug degenerates into a place for people to call each other names, I guarantee you that it
Having said that, you need to understand that I am absolutely 100% NOT trying to be arrogant, and I
recognize that this issue is currently causing you grief. I'm going to discuss this with the developers
and I will annotate this PR with a better description of the current situation by the end this week.
In the mean time here are some things to keep in mind:
1) This really is an enhancement request, not a bug. There are many, many Eclipse (and Eclipse based
commercial product) users that do not need this feature. You're use case is *very* real, but it does not
impact the vast majority of people who use Eclipse.
2) Architecturally, this is not a simple enhancement for Eclipse to make. If it was, it just outright WOULD
have been implented by now. Man, for something that seems so obvious, line termination is
unbelievably pervasive and subtle. As has already been noted, both operating systems and VCM
systems typically want to control line terminaters, but there are other factors. Are the rules different for
specific ""kinds"" of text files? At what granularity do we allow these to be set? Where is the information
stored? Even just ""What *is* a text file?"" isn't an easy question to answer.
In any case, as I said above, I'll get back to you with more info once I have it. In the mean time, if you're
going to flame me, *please* remember to be civil while you're doing it.

3970,daniel_megert@ch.ibm.com,2005-04-27T09:32:54Z,60,0,"Just a side note, it does not fix the problem but might improve the situation a
little bit: for 3.1 the line delimiter conversion has been improved to work over

3970,Mike_Wilson@ca.ibm.com,2005-04-29T20:15:41Z,61,0,"Ok. I've talked to most of the teams that are potentially effected by this, and here's what I found...
In the current Eclipse R3.1 development builds the following support for custom line separators already
exists [yes, you probably know this already]:
1) When opened on an existing text file that contains line separators, the standard Eclipse editors
detect which line separator the file uses, and continue to use that one as new lines are added. This
should prevent ""mixed"" line separators from appearing in files.
2) The CVS repository provider (i.e. the Eclipse code we wrote to talk to CVS) has a preference checkbox
Convert text files to use platform line ending"", which can be found in the ""Files and Folders"" tab of the
CVS"" preference page (under the ""Team"" preference page). By default this preference is checked, but if
you *uncheck* it, CVS will not modify the line separators of text files when they are checked out of (or
into) CVS. This, together with point 1), should allow a team with developers working on multiple
platforms to work with existing text files without causing the line separator to be modified.
3) As Dani mentioned above, the ""File"" > ""Convert Line Delimiters To"" menu operation can now be
applied to whatever is selected, be they files, folders or projects. This should allow wholesale
conversion of existing text files without grief.
Honestly, I think this already a pretty good story, but none of it actually addresses the feature
requested by this bug: ""UI needed to define the default line delimiters for new files"". So here's what
we're going to do [To be clear, THESE FEATURES ARE NOT YET IN]:
1) We'll provide a per-project preference that allows you to choose what you want the default line
separator to be for new text files created in that project. By putting it on the project, the value will be
shared with the project. This, together with the features described above, lets a team of developers
working on the shame project always use a particular line separator both when editing existing files
2) We'll provide the same kind of preference for the workspace as a whole. This will be used for projects
that do not explicitly have the preference set. Note that, if you want the line separator setting to ""stick""
to your work, you will want to use the project setting rather than this one (because even if you weren't
sharing the project, you would have to remember re-set it every time you got a new workspace).
3) We'll modify the standard places where text files are created to detect and use these properties. One
*very* important thing to keep in mind about this is that, we don't have control over all of the text file
creating tools that have been written by the Eclipse community. Some of these, by nature of how they
fit into the underlying frameworks, may do the right thing with the new preferences, some probably
won't. I presume you will take on the task of evangelizing the need to support this new capability with
the authors of the plugins you care about. ;-)
So... the intent is to get this in before R3.1 ships. Because we are so close to the end of the cycle -- our
M7 milestone, which is our first release candidate, is in two weeks -- I'm still pretty worried that we
won't get all of the cases right, so it will be important for you to do serious testing once we do get the
code in. I can't even promise that the code will be in for M7; it may slip past it by a week or so, so you'll
That better not be a Freudian slip. :-)

3979,erich_gamma@ch.ibm.com,2002-05-04T17:36:08Z,8,0,I agree on the importance but the issue is that the decoration is done by the
CVSDecorator using the IResource adapter. It therefore can only know about the
resource hierarchy. Similarly, the Java views cannot know about the CVS
decorations. All they do is to map LabelProviderChangedEvents for IResources
One idea was to show two different dirty indicators on containers:
- ""logically"" dirty - the container contains dirty children
To make this happen would require VCM support for hooking into the CVS
decoration. This is unlikely to happen for 2.0 (unless Kevin disagrees).
Finally, as a weak argument - the problem only shows up when the ""Compute Deep
Outgoing change for folders"" is on.
3979,Kevin_McGuire@ca.ibm.com,2002-05-06T16:55:41Z,9,0,I would love to solve this but we have no solution for 2.0."
3979,dirk_baeumer@ch.ibm.com,2002-07-25T16:53:11Z,10,0,"Kevin, any plans to give JDT the change to influence this ?"
1. We can stop showing dirty indicators on parents.  To find out if you have
projects with changes, you'ld need to perform a query.  This has certain
performance gains as well since you don't have to check the dirty status for
all elements of a project (expensive and doesn't scale as projects increase in
2. Something else which understands the logical parenting in the packages
view.  All we have here is the problem description; we have no solution to

I assume that you talk about the breakpoints view contributed
by the ""org.eclipse.debug.ui"" plugin. The mechanisms how the vertical
ruler and the breakpoints view look up icons differ. The breakpoints
view has specific knowledge about markers representing breakpoints,
whereas the vertical ruler does not assume a specific marker type.
If you create a marker which should be rendered independently of
its state, the following is recommended: You specify a particular icon
for a particular marker type in your plugin.xml file, e.g.:
Your definition is picked up by all editors relying on the provided
If  you create a marker that should be rendered depending on
its state, you have to provide an Annotation which masters the
required rendering. In addition, you have to make sure that for
your marker your custom annotation is created. If you deal with
your own IAnnotationModel, it depends on your implementation
how your annotation is created and added to the  model. If you
use, e.g., the ResourceAnnotationModel, you can create a subclass
of MarkerAnnotation, say MyMarkerAnnotation, and subclass
to return MyMarkerAnnotation. Thus, when building an editor, you have
to configure it with document providers which return your custom
ResourceAnnotationModel. As example look at JDT. They provide their
We are looking into simplifying this for the future.

As a simple test, I changeded the XMLMemento#putString(String, String) method
public void putString(String key, String value) {
I tested this by writing a few lines of code including tabs and newlines in the
display view and shutting down Eclipse. Since DisplayView#saveState(IMemento)
calls XMLMemento#putString(String, String) without first modifying the value
String (other than trmming leading and trailing whitespace), putString takes as
input the original contents of the view, including the tabs and newlines
(except leading and trailing tabs and newlines).
It turns out that the String fed to setAttribute and the String retrieved from
getAttribute are equal (x is always true). All of the tabs and newline
characters which are present in the input String are retrieved, so the xerces
plug-in is not eliminating tab or newline characters."

Added to IMemento in package org.eclipse.ui:
These methods are used to store Text (also known as Character Data) to an
IMemento. Unlike the getString/putString methods of IMemento, these methods
cause white space to be persisted.
Each IMemento is allowed only one Text node. When putTextData(String data) is
called, data replaces the previous value of the Text node of the IMemento. For
example, if the following code was executed, then getTextData would
To use these methods, call putTextData(String value) and getTextData() where
you would previously call putString(String key, String value) and getString

4392,veronika_irvine@yahoo.com,2001-10-11T18:16:00Z,0,0,"When you run the following example, you will see that after the two columns, there is some extra space in the table.
What is happening is as follows:
1) Table always has the style bits SWT.H_SCROLL  and SWT.V_SCROLL set whether you set them or not:

column3: * Feature in Windows.  It is not possible to create
* a table that does not have scroll bars.  Therefore,
* no matter what style bits are specified, set the
* H_SCROLL and V_SCROLL bits so that the SWT style
* will match the widget that Windows creates.

column1: 2) In computeSize (which is called by GridLayout), Table always
calculates the space needed for the scroll bars regardless of
whether they are to be displayed or not:

column2: Table::public Point computeSize (int wHint, int hHint, boolean changed) {

column1: I commented out the lines in computeSize that were adding the
width of the scrollbar to the total width and I did not see the extra space.

column3: VI to indicate what the right answer is.
SWT always allows extra space for scrollbars that might show up,
even if they never show up. This is true for all widgets: List, Tree, Table, etc.
If we take away the extra space, a scrollbar can pop up and obscure list items,
and the user has no way of seeing what is under the scrollbar (i.e. items are clipped).
In most widgets, the extra space for a potential scrollbar looks fine - in fact it is what the user expects.
The only widget this is a problem for is Table - because Table has vertical lines between the columns,
and the extra space for the vertical scrollbar actually looks ""tacked on"". i.e. it looks as if someone
added a skinny extra column on the right, which is suspiciously the width of a scrollbar.
Here's the problem - the native Table always provides scrollbars, whether or not they are displayed,
i.e. even if the application doesn't want them and doesn't put enough items in the Table to need them.
One possible (hack) solution is to keep a boolean slot that keeps track of whether or not the application
created the widget with VSCROLL. If they did not, we can assume that they prefer not to have the extra space.
This could cause more problems than it solves, however, and since the Eclipse team seems to have
found another way around the problem, this PR should go to Inactive."

4394,ljpm27@gmail.com,2008-06-18T07:45:27Z,10,0,"one might always argue that if the original mandate also included 'a rational design' on top of the aforementioned ""efficient, portable, native"", it might be possible to consider that using interfaces to bridge commonalities would 'go without saying', in which case this would not be an enhancement, but fixing one of the longest lasting design deficiencies of SWT. but again I am no expert... "

Please L. Mihalkovic, stick to technical discussions or specific problems you are facing when trying to use the toolkit to ship products.  Implying that a particular software design is not rational just isn't helpful."

4394,ljpm27@gmail.com,2008-06-18T18:56:17Z,12,0,"Well Steve Northover, I am having to do all sorts of contortions in my code (not unlike what the previous commenter suggested) to overcome what you seem to view as a unnecessary / undesirable enhancement, which I and many other people for that matter, seem to consider as a real design flaw.

Having spent a fair amount of time inside the guts of the workbench, I can say, like many others before me, and probably even like some people from IBM say among themselves, that there is a fair bit of redundant code in the way toolbars/items/contributions are handled. At this point, the mix of FINAL declarations (SWT), use of package visible methods (SWT), checking of what can be derived and from where (SWT), and use of class names rather than generic interface (WORKBENCH) make it a crazy endeavor to try to retrofit new types of menu controls (or in my case, make it possible to switch transparently between types of widget to implement menus) inside the workbench.

Aside from the number of generations of design inside the workbench code (I am referring to the ""this is part of a work in progress""), the root cause of the problem is a general absence of evolvability in the design of the core widget set:  I am referring to absence of common abstractions for certain shared behaviors described in this post and others, or the difficulties to extend what is already there.

Without taking away from the achievement that SWT was when it came out almost 10 years ago, and has managed to remain, I think it is healthy to allow criticism of one's work, especially when one makes the choice to make said work public. I cannot help but wonder how much longer you will be able to discard unwelcomed observations by pushing them into the bowls of bugzilla.

4394,snorthov@ca.ibm.com,2008-06-18T20:33:38Z,13,0,Sigh.  Please give descriptions of classes that are final and methods that are package visible that are giving you problems.  Remember that only the public API is the same between platforms so, for exampe, a method that is package visible on Windows may not be present on GTK.
> (or in my case, make it possible to switch transparently between
> types of widget to implement menus)

Certainly you are in trouble here.  For example, switching in your own menu bar and remaining native just isn't happening on platforms such as Windows and the Mac.  In the case of Windows, the menu bar is hard wired into the window trim.  On the Mac, the menu bar is at the top of the display.
I don't mind criticism but I think you need to do a little research before assuming that everything is wrong or poorly designed."
4394,ljpm27@gmail.com,2008-06-18T22:03:55Z,14,0,"> Remember that only the public API is the same between platforms so, for exampe, a method that
> is package visible on Windows may not be present on GTK.

I would really have to be a complete idiot to not have understood that after several years of continuous use of SWT...  the fact that I added support for mac sheets to a number of dialogs and created the option to transfered the perspective switcher to a native mac toolbar controlled by a custom presentation could be mistaken for cues that I might have actually understood that and a couple of other simple facts about SWT.

On my off-work time, I am trying to build a portable Cairo backed GC implementation for all the platforms supported by Cairo. I built the basic capabilities showing that it works [tested on win and macos].  Not wanting to have to convince you that it might be beneficial, I took the route of building a EGC (extended GC) which of course bumped into the fact that GC is final (and so is Device). these and other symptoms are the reasons that make me, and it seems other people (as witnessed by some of the other posts in these bugzilla entries), say that there are some design flaws in SWT.

I will grant you that some of them are simply the result of an increasing level of sophistication in the usage patterns of SWT (i.e. SWT falling victim to its success), but conversely, you would have to grant me (and many others) that others are the result of some avoidable (or correctable over time) design shortcomings.

Here is one more specific case, this one falling into the category of un-anticipated direction [YES, I realize that this is not where you will want this comment entered]: at the moment, Cairo.java contains some platform and non-platform specific code. Considering that one of the core principles of SWT seem to keep the two separate, it would not have been a far fetched idea to create a CairoPlatform (or whatever you want to call it) class that would contain only the OS specific code (surface + font). So I say it is unfortunate that the Cairo support was not directly designed that way (a shared Cairo.java + a specific CairoPlatform.java).

No big deal... [I did that so that I would be able to access the font and surface apis on each of the native platforms].  But when you start down that path, you realize how much each implementation of SWT looks very different from the others, even when there are some serious real commonalities, or even when it would make sense from a strict design/elegance point of view to structure them more similarly. Now, this comment is about the insides of SWT, but it is equally applicable to the outside (the public API) that lacks some levels of common abstraction where it might have made sense from a OO point of view to have them (this bugzilla entry is certainly not the only one point at this design deficiency).
> I don't mind criticism but I think you need to do a little research before
> assuming that everything is wrong or poorly designed.
Read my post again, and you will notice that you are reading ""everything"" where I only referred to ""some things""
4394,snorthov@ca.ibm.com,2008-06-18T23:06:44Z,15,0,First off, yes there are design flaws in SWT!

The class GC was not intended to be subclassed.  It was not written such that a person could subclass it, reimplement certain methods and get something useful.  Furthermore, it's implementation is platform specific and as such, could fall victim to the dynamic version of the fragile superclass problem.  Instances of GC are created automatically within the toolkit, for example during paint events.  For subclassing to be supported, hooks would be needed to support an alternate GC implementation. But more to the point, it is written to be as fast as possible and not intended to be pluggable.  The idea here was to avoid all possible extra overhead and complexity in design.  Since GC is not intended to be pluggable, then pluggability was not coded into the implementation.  Should this situation change, then refactoring the code will be necessary.

The class Device is not final.  It is subclassed by Printer from outside of the graphics package.  The implementation however, is very platform specific.  The idea here is to allow printing to be removed from SWT by deleting the printing package.

I do agree that the implementation of SWT could be restructured.  In the beginning, there was an effort to avoid layers such as implemenation peers for performance reasons.  Restructuring and retesting everything at this point would be a big effort, something that might make sense for e4."
4394,ljpm27@gmail.com,2008-06-19T01:58:15Z,16,0,"> The class Device is not final
> The idea here is to allow printing to be removed from SWT by deleting the printing

trust me, it is not difficult to infer some of the rules that went into the design from the package structure. some of these idea even show their age... for example who would today choose to design a graphic API using ints for the coordinate system (yet there was a time when I used to live by Michael Abrash's DDJ column on hand optimized assembly language integer arithmetic libraries)
>For subclassing to be supported, hooks would be needed to support an
>alternate GC implementation. But more to the point, it is written to be as fast
>as possible and not intended to be pluggable.  The idea here was to avoid all
>possible extra overhead and complexity in design.  Since GC is not intended to
>be pluggable, then pluggability was not coded into the implementation.  Should
>this situation change, then refactoring the code will be necessary.

hence my comment about ""un-anticipated direction"" which meant ""I know that you guys did not forsee, much less want to encourage derivation of the GC type"".  However, my comment related to design was about the fact that despite some remarkable levels of similarities between them all the GC seem to follow there own local implementation rules.

the problem I see is that in the name of making things simple, you have also closed the door to some things that people could do on their own to bring some simple improvements to SWT. Forget weak super class and hooks, and all these grand ideas...  I couldn't do something as simple as add Porter Duff alpha compositing without compiling my own version of SWT (I added ""GC.setComposite(...)"" )

4394,viliam@mailbox.sk,2008-06-19T12:06:47Z,17,0,We need common interfaces for another simple thing: We develop a framework that generates UIs and has a control factory to create controls. Control factory can generate either, say, Label or CLabel, Combo or CCombo or even custom implementation etc. Common interfaces would make such thing lot easier: look at the code of org.eclipse.jface.viewers.ComboViewer: it's source would be one half shorter with ICombo, and even able to use other Combo-like implementations.
I workaround it by defining my own interfaces and subclassing like this:
public class StandardButton extends Button implements IButton {
It works for me except for CCombo (see bug 235968) and Table/TreeItems of virtual tables (i.e. not created by me).

4394,ljpm27@gmail.com,2008-06-20T00:56:49Z,18,0,"so that is another example of ""final"" class that should probably not be final, considering that similarly scoped classes are not.  today I was also reminded of ""error(int)"" which is used internally everywhere, does nothing spectacularly dangerous that would warrant protecting it, and yet is only package accessible...

These, and other signs, are what make me think that ""evolvability"" did not rank very high in the list of design goals for SWT. to me, these issues create the impression that SWT was more meant as an embedded GUI API, or as a fixed simple public API, than as a evolvable foundation layer (the scope of this comment is very specific and is not a general judgement of other aspects of SWT).

Even if it did more, the intent is for it to clean up any operating system state as necessary before throwing the exception.  For example, a mouse grab might be released on a button.  This would be reimplemented on a widget by widget basis, depending on exactly when and where the error occurred.  As an API, it would make no sense to be used outside of the package."
4394,ljpm27@gmail.com,2008-06-21T03:22:26Z,20,0,"> L. Mihalkovic, error(int) just calls SWT.error().
geez S.N., thank you for pointing it out ...   after spending hours scouting through the source to build a Mac/Win/Linux Cairo backed version of GC, I wonder how I could miss that one ... .....
> Even if it did more, the intent is for it to clean up any operating system
> state as necessary before throwing the exception.  For example, a mouse grab
> might be released on a button.  This would be re-implemented on a widget by
> widget basis, depending on exactly when and where the error occurred.  As an
> API, it would make no sense to be used outside of the package.

This is where I (I can't imagine being the only one) see an inconsistency between your design decisions and the reality of the SWT code: I can appreciate that you have decided (prerogative of the chief designer) that ""it is limited to a widget per widget scope"".  Fine, then by all means, make it so... consistently.  And as the chief implementor, ensure that your design rules are followed by you and others, and that each widget uses its very own local implementation.  But that is not how the code is written, and in many cases the default widget set is re-using the base implementation.  So there is the idea that it is ""per widget"", the reality that most of them actually share it, and the limitation that it is not really ALL the widgets, because anything created by third parties in a different package name than ""org.eclipse.swt"" would not be able to access it.  Someone smarter than me said that ""principles are the things we hang on to when it is hard to do it"".

I chose this example because it was almost trivial, and therefore suited to convey an idea.  But there are many more like that one, some of them not so ridiculous, like for the instance the problem referenced by this bugzilla entry.  Starting to understand why I wonder if SWT is in a sense more extensible by accident than by design?

the point I have been trying to make in multiple instances, and which has more often than not been swiftly brushed away (or discarded in favor or pointing out some menial details in the posts), is that SWT is full of these inconsistencies, or sometimes unfinished ideas (the latter is more true of the platform code than of SWT).  And what I have noticed while reading hundreds of past bug entries is that there is a pattern of not revisiting these annoyances/inconsistencies between successive versions.  Thinking about the 100s of millions of dollars resting on this technology, I simply question wether it is fitting the current level of responsibility resting on SWT and the eclipse core.  Frankly, I am rather scared to see the core team everyone gun-hoe about a JavaScript version of SWT when so many serious entries, like this one, have been pending a real resolution for years (this is another good one: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=235968).

4394,ljpm27@gmail.com,2008-06-21T03:28:05Z,21,0,And just to clarify, I say ""have been pending a real resolution for years"", because some of these problems (like this one in particular) have had some rippling effect inside the rest of the Workbench code or the code developed outside.  I am for example referring to the level of redundancy in the various ContributionManager's code - see fill(xxxxx) where xxxxx is which ever container du-jour... are you going to tell me this is the best 20 years of Object Oriented design refinement has to offer?!

Here is another example of the lack of evolvability of SWT (I say this one due to inconsistency):  the ""display"" field is to the ""Widget"" hierarchy what the ""device"" field is to the ""Resource"" hierarchy.  Then why the difference in their treatment:  the Widget constructor takes care of setting ""display"", while there is no way to set ""device"" from a custom build Resource"" (Widget constructor is public while Resource constructor is package only).

Now, I know that if there is an answer at all, it will be closer to ""but why do you mess with your own Resource type. there is really no scenario at all where you would need to"", than to a ""hmmm... interesting.. let me see if there might be a case for that, it could simply be that we overlooked it""...  but the optimistic in me keeps seeking the ""Open"" part of ""Open Source"" in places where it does not seem to have been implemented yet.

column2: While trying to ""beautify"" VAME for Motif I've got the impression that the Motif implementation
(for obvious reasons) lacks some ""coordination"" between the visual elements.
Coordination"" means: It should be possible to compose larger controls from single controls without
having to know how a specific control looks on every platform. This requires careful upfront tuning of sizes, borders, gaps
so that things line up nicely, double borders are avoided etc. and this all without too many tweaks in client code.
A classical example is how to align a label and a button so that the text baselines
line up independent of the size of both controls and the fonts used.
I'm not asking for all that right now, but it would be nice if we can state some basic invariants,
which are independent from a platform.
See first: 1FSA2CS: SWT:DCR - Visual coordination of SWT controls!
(Tree w/o Border) inside (Composite w Border) == (Tree w Border)
A borderless Tree (or Text, Table, etc.) as the single child of a Composite with border has identical
appearance as a Tree with border.
(If not then I'm in trouble because I cannot write an adorned viewer whose visual
appearance matches the native one; right now this seems to be true on Windows but not on Motif)
Added AW's comments from March 23 and moved 1FSA2CS to ZZ-Trash.

column3: To some extent, appearance differences between platforms are simply a *direct* outcome
of our decision to use platform widgets with as little ""playing with defaults"" as possible.
We still strongly believe that as soon as you (actually, we) start changing the defaults which
the platform is providing for the widgets, we get in to trouble. The perfect example of this is
the well known ""widgets don't change colour when you change the Appearance control
panel values"" problem, where if you explicitely set window colors, then the o/s won't update
them for you when users request it.
In all honestly, we don't have time to deal with these issues in this cycle anyway.

4400,knut_radloff@us.ibm.com,2001-10-11T18:16:08Z,0,0,"Issues to clean up the SWT API/make it smaller.

column2: - May want to rename isSelected(int) to getSelection(int).
We have a rule to use get* if possible.
- Punt Table.isSelected and replace with Table.getItem(int).getSelection()
- Should have common API for setSelection, select, deselect, remove that take an int []
- Get rid of select, deselect, remove that take int or int, int
- Implement showItem that takes a TreeItem/TableItem/String
- Get rid of showSelection.  People can implement showSelection using
- Need to decide on setSelection() that takes an array of items. Should we also have
select, deselect, remove that take an array of items?
- Keep showSelection(). Text is different from Tree/Table/List anyway because it's not
item based. Don't try to make the API look like the Tree/Table/List API.
- setPageIncrement, setThumb names are confusing. The latter sets the size of the
scroll thumb to reflect the page size (for proportional scroll bars) or to any value
setPageIncrement specifies the scroll amount for page scrolling. They bascially do
the same thing but both need to be there in order to allow non-proportional scroll bars.

column3: -setPageSize, setThumbSize. Problem with these: they only  take an int-basically
the height. Other setXYZsize API takes a Point.

column2: Since JFace has to implement reparenting I need API on Tree, Table, List, etc. for setting the focus item.
Without this reparenting isn't transparent because a reparented viewer resets the focus item always to the first item.

column3: List has a package visibility method ""setFocusIndex"" which appears to be what
you are looking for. We need to look at providing this for all appropriate widgets
and make it public. We should probably do this even if it is *not* possible to do
it on linux, since the re-parenting capability is only available on windows anyway.
This is not possible on the Tree widget in Windows. Agree that the current
behavior is not nice, but we are unsure what to do."

column2: Thanks.  I stepped through the code and changed it slightly so that the tree
would be visible.  It appears that Tree.deselectAll () is working fine but that
deleting the focus item (whether selected or not) causes another another
node to become the focus item and get selected.
How important is this problem?  I have verifed that you are getting a selection
callback when the new item is selected.
We have a workaround that tries to avoid the sequence of deselectAll and dispose calls.
It seems to work for now.
Thanks.  The real problem is that the Windows tree really hates to have nothing
selected.  For example, if you set focus to a tree that has nothing selected, Windows
will select an item.  There are other cases.
What I'm getting at is that despite how bogus this is, it may be a case of platform
behavior that we have to live with.

column3: I agree with the above explanation. Moving to inactive."

4410,christophe.cornu+eclipse@gmail.com,2004-06-21T19:42:20Z,4,0,"SWT can be invoked into a signed applet pending the swt native library is
manually copied over to the jre/bin folder used by the Java plugin runtime -
the same way the AWT library relies on the awt.dll to be in the jre bin folder.
1. build the jar containing the java applet containing all your applet classes
AND all the SWT files present in the Windows SWT jar. Sign the resulting jar.
Windows SWT jar and corresponding native library are available from the
2. copy the swt native libraries over the jre/bin folder used by the java
plugin. To determine the location of the jre/bin folder on Windows XP do:
Control Panel > Java > Java tab > Java Runtime Settings > View > Location
3. applet can be started through HTML file assuming step 2 has been completed
Process would be simplified if SWT shipped with the Java JRE. Another approach
is to develop an SWT plugin for IE to run sweetlets (bug 37707)."

column2: If I open a Shell which is already open it is brought to front under Windows but not on Motif.
Should I always use a Shell.moveAbove(null) after calling Shell.open()?
This is a bug.  The intent of shell.open () is that it be only called once but when called
multiple times, it should bring the shell to the front like Windows (I guess ... ?).  You
shouldn't really be calling it multiple times but it's not harmful.  To change the Z-order,
you should be using the Z-order calls (moveAbove etc.).

column3: Clarification: It is a bug in application code to call Shell.open() more than once.
Applications should not rely on this behavior. We should probably make open
throw an SWTException if it is called, but this is low priority. Moving to inactive."

4417,snorthov@ca.ibm.com,2003-04-04T23:12:30Z,16,0,"Ok, the attatchments are in but there seems to be two copies of the source in
Let me describe the state of the world.  On Solaris, where AWT is dynamically
linked, the AWTandSWT example works but the low level locking issues in SWT
and AWT have not been resolved.  This example runs AWT in one shell and SWT in
another.  On Solaris, the AWTinSWT example hangs.  This example embeds AWT in
SWT, the thing that would need to be done for Eclipse.
On Linux, when AWT is dynamically linked, we expect that we will get the same
behavior as Solaris.  This mean that we can move on to the locking and hanging
4417,snorthov@ca.ibm.com,2003-04-08T23:47:13Z,17,0,"When I run the SWT_AWT bridge class on Solaris, it looks like Motif is sending
a fake XFocusChange from the wrong thread.  The event appears to be coming in
on the SWT thread from the AWT thread.  I hacked SWT to get rid of the thread
check (this is wrong) and got farther to another hang.  Also, funny things are
happening with the X and Xt error handlers, depeding on the load order of the
It seems that we will need the source for AWT in order to debug this because
we are just guessing and what AWT is doing."
SWTInSWT (""works"" on Motif only, tested on Linux)
Embedding one SWT in another SWT within the same process is similar to
embedding AWT in SWT.  In the example, the ""Inner SWT"" is created from a handle
provided by the ""Outer SWT"", simulating an inner AWT created from an outer SWT.
This code currently works on Motif only.
While SWTInSWT is hardly a comprehensive test case, it seems to work well
enough and provides a good start, showing that it is possible to embed two one
window in another where each window is serviced by a different event loop.
NOTE:  You will need the latest SWT from HEAD to run the example."
4417,brockway@us.ibm.com,2003-10-09T18:32:23Z,20,0,"Working on a project that is using Eclipse technology as it's base. It has
recently become a requirement to be able to embed Java Swing JComponets inside
of eclipse views. Specifically, we need to take existing JPanels that contain
other Swing JComponents and embed them in an Eclipse view. The JPanel will be
the only contents of said view (i.e. we don't need to mix and match AWT, SWT
and Swing compoents in the view). Could someone answer the following questions:
Is this functionality going to make it into Eclipse 3.0 and released in June
Will there be support for Windows XP and Linux GTK?
We have something working but largely untested on Windows.  On Motif and GTK,
we have something working that supports the XEmbed protocol.  Should AWT
implement this protocol, then we would interop with AWT/Swing as well as any
other X Windows based toolkit.  I encourage you to browse the Sun web site to
determine whether they are planning to support XEmbed.
> Is this functionality going to make it into Eclipse 3.0 and released
We are currently stuck on the Mac.
4417,snorthov@ca.ibm.com,2004-01-05T21:18:51Z,22,0,The interop code has been released in org.eclipse.swt.awt.  The code works for
Windows. For GTK and Motif, JDK 1.5 is required."

column2: The example ScrollBitmapExample passes incorrect values to method setThumb().
2) resize the window so that it sometimes is larger than the image, sometimes smaller.

column3: -> as long the window is smaller than the image the scrollbar's thumbs have the correct size.
But if the window is larger the size of the thumbs appear to be random.
You would expect that the thumb disappears (since there is nothing to scroll)
or at least fill the scrollbar completely.
But this doesn't happen because of PR 1FRQRNK: SWT:ALL - ScrollBar setters exit early silently.
Agree that the example is bogus. Low priority. Moving to inactive."

column2: Dean: - TrackBar needs to be fixed
- redraw of all child widgets is not implemented
- ProgressBar, ScrollBar and Slider need to be fixed.  Rationalized and Xerrors turned off.
- computeSize () for each widget (see 1FDQ1HT: SWT:AIX - Need computeSize () for each widget)
- Text widget password char and SWT.Verify not implemented
- Radio button behaviour for radio buttons in group.
- check that all Object slots are null'd when a widget is disposed
- check that all handle slots are zero'd when a widget is disposed
- Z-order of widgets needs to change when moveAbove()/moveBelow()
- clearSelection() for list deprecated.  Check all public API for others.

4426,knut_radloff@us.ibm.com,2001-10-11T18:16:36Z,0,0,"There is no way to query the size of a ScrollBar. getBounds is not public.

column2: I need this in order to implement computeSize for DrawnTree and Table.
You don't need getBounds for ScrollBar because this relies on the current
bounds of the window.  You need to query the default width and height of a
scroll bar (ie. OS.GetSystemMetrics (OS.SM_CXVSCROLL)).  Can't you use
computeTrim()?  You should be able to.
What I really wanted is the height/width of the scroll bar. Not the complete
computeTrim() does indeed give me the scroll bar width (+ border width).
So I guess computeTrim() should do the job for me.
I may get burned though if you change Tree.computeSize because you
don't use computeTrim(). Shouldn't you use computeTrim() in
Tree.computeSize() to ensure that all trimmings are calculated correctly?
It seems that you do pretty much the same thing computeTrim does.
While trying to ""beautify"" VAME for Motif I've got the impression that the Motif implementation
(for obvious reasons) lacks some ""coordination"" between the visual elements.
Coordination"" means: It should be possible to compose larger controls from single controls without
having to know how a specific control looks on every platform. This requires careful upfront tuning of sizes, borders, gaps
so that things line up nicely, double borders are avoided etc. and this all without too many tweaks in client code.
A classical example is how to align a label and a button so that the text baselines
line up independent of the size of both controls and the fonts used.
I'm not asking for all that right now, but it would be nice if we can state some basic invariants,
which are independent from a platform.
See first: 1FSA2CS: SWT:DCR - Visual coordination of SWT controls!
Width and horizontal position of vertical scrollbar matches size and position of arrowbutton in Combo.
(See top left Pane in LF's Repository browser)
FYI: The ""drop down"" arrow and ""scroll bar"" arrow in Windows are different bitmaps
and have been different sizes and looked different in the past (Windows 3.11).

4434,christophe.cornu+eclipse@gmail.com,2003-03-07T16:14:35Z,4,0,I believe bug 33834 could be a variant of this test case.
We are testing a workaround for this bug 4434 (and we are trying to understand
the scope under which this problem occurs). This should also provide a fix for bug
With a recent version of SWT (>= Eclipse 2.1 RC1), the test case in this PR causes
- within the expand callback, a tree item is disposed
- SWT removes the tree item from the tree table.
- TVM_DELETEITEM is called to destroy the OS tree item.
The problem is that, for some reason, this TVM_DELETEITEM causes a
TVN_ITEMEXPANDING resulting in another SWT.Expand event. At this stage,
the OS considers the tree item to still be there (TVM_GETITEM etc return it), but it
has already been removed from the SWT tree table.
- this causes TreeItem.getItems() to possibly return an array with a null item,
causing the NPE. (remember: we are all here still before returning from the call to
One workaround is to detect that case by checking for a null item in
test case which was causing the stack trace"

4435,lynne_kues@us.ibm.com,2001-10-11T18:16:45Z,0,0,"Why doesn't a RowLayout within a RowLayout wrap?  See the RowLayout example.  If

column2: you size it such that the nested RowLayout doesn't fit within the width of the shell, it is

column3: Doing this would require a considerably more complex algorithm than
the currently provided one. It sounds like a desirable feature, but we would
need to investigate further. Unlikely to happen this release."

column1: 4435,snorthov@ca.ibm.com,2002-02-13T15:25:06Z,1,0,"This isn't really a bug.  The nested RowLayout is at it's preferred size which
is the size of the children, without wrapping.  If the application would like
the nested RowLayout to wrap, it's up to the application to hook resize
callbacks and tell the nested row column what it's width should be, causing it
to wrap.  There is no way that the nested RowLayout can decide when it should
wrap based on the size of the shell it's in.
The only possibility would be to add an ""adjustLast"" or ""stretch"" flag that
would stretch the last item in the row to take up the space left over.  This
would cause the inner RowLayout to be resized to be too small when it wraps in
the shell and then it would also wrap.  It would also cause the buttons and
labels to be stretched as well.
We could implement this but it seems a bit goofy.  The inner RowLayout would
wrap as a side effect of being ""stretched"" but the look of the other widgets
would change in the layout as well.
Specifying a number of columns for grid layout and then not providing enough
widgets to fill the columns causes NullPointerException.  Perhaps this could be
An SWT tree doesn't seem to have proper keyboard support.  Since multiple
selection is supported, there needs to be a way to do it via keyboard navigation.
So one would expect to be able to move the emphasis box using ctrl-up and
ctrl-down, space should select and deselect, and enter should do the same as
double click. In other words, one would expect the same standard keyboard support
as for a native list widget.

column2: There are several problems showing icons for actions on menus:

column4: There are no icons at all on WinNT.   Win98 and Win2000 do shown icons on menus.
If an action is disabled on a menu, the icon correctly shows as disabled.
However, if you mouse over the action, the hover icon is shown.
When mousing over disabled icons on a toolbar, the disabled icon doesn't change.
Actions that are enabled show on menus with the colored hover icon.
Actions on toolbars that are enabled show the uncolored enabled icon.
Example: The Search action on the workbench toolbar and Edit menu.
When hovering over a toolbar action, in addition to the colored hover icon, you get
a 3D effect.  For consistency, this would be nice on menus as well.  Is this
possible?  Example:  MS Word does this.

column1: 4442,knut_radloff@us.ibm.com,2002-07-01T21:44:48Z,1,0,"Platforms don't allow consistent vertical centering behavior."
You will get a NullPointerException because label2 spans two columns
and there is only one column left on the first row.
If you change the span of label2 to be more than the number of columns
in the grid layout (ie. gridData.horizontalSpan = layout.numColumns + 1;)

column5: // comment this line out and it works

column2: The layout is defined incorrectly, so this is user error.  These are the kinds
of things I wanted to pick up with exceptions, but SN wasn't keen on the idea of
introducing exceptions for incorrect layout specification.
The programmer should never get a NullPointerException or ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
That would lead people to believe that there's a bug in the SWT layout code instead
of pointing them to a mistake in their layout code.
If the programmer defines a layout incorrectly, a corresponding exception should
be thrown. A general exception like InvalidLayoutData should be good enough.
An option would be to ignore the offending widget and not lay it out at all. That
way the programmer would see that there's something wrong with the layout spec.
We should sort this out when we do the SWT exception pass.

column3: This seems like another instance of having better exception support
as described in 1FEA8ZE: SWT:ALL - When to throw exceptions.

column1: Fix is to place label2 on the next row and to limit the horizontal span to be
no bigger than the number of columns in the layout.

column2: How/where do you update the item text? The cheese you see is caused by the
tree item not knowing about changes to the item text.
You have to call TreeItem.setText if you are going to render a different text.
Otherwise the tree item can't recalculate the new item length.
This problem will go away when we no longer have custom renderers.
No longer a problem since custom renderers are no longer supported. Moved to Inactive

column3: Does not appear to be related to custom renderers. I.e. The problem
should be reproduceable using application code."

column2: One way to reduce the number of adapter classes for typed listeners is to
bring down the number of methods in the corresponding listener interface to one.
(In this case you don't need default implementations for the methods you are not interested in,
so you don't need an adapter).
Folding listener methods into one especially makes sense if the typical  handler code is similar.
On the other hand a field has to be added to the typed event to distinguish the different cases.
I've looked through the listeners and found the following interfaces where the above applies IMHO:
By doing this it would be possible to eliminate 5 of 8 adapters.
One way to reduce the number of classes it to go back to untyped events.
This will get rid of every class.
The other thing to do is get rid of the Adaptors and make JFACE define only
the ones they actually use.  Obviously, if JFACE uses them all, then there
is no win.  I have already suggested this to Kevin.
Does Erich agree that these should be collapsed?

column3: Nothing will be done about this at this time."

column1: 4445,Mike_Wilson@ca.ibm.com,2002-03-20T19:39:05Z,2,0,The Adapter API is frozen. No changes will be made to it.

column2: JFace legacy provides a CellContainer that is used heavily in existing

column1: JFace applications. Providing something similar in JFace would simplify
the migration to JFace2000. We have tried to implement CellContainer on top of GridLayout, but
the models are too different and we had to give up. The major difference is that
in CellContainer (which is based on GridBagLayout) you can position a widget
directly by giving coordinates e.g. 3, 4 and you don't have to worry about empty cells.
Emulating this with the GridLayout would require to insert dummy filler widgets into
empty cells. This is clumsy and wastes resources.
Notice: the priority of this PR depends on how important backward compatibility

column3: Nothing will be done about this at this time."

The embedded profiler has a situation where program control of item positioning
in a tree widget is needed (similar to setTopIndex() for List).
After looking a bit at the code and at the Win Common Controls spec, I have
discovered the following:  It looks like the setSelection() method in Tree sends
the TVM_SELECTITEM message with the TVGN_CARET flag to set the
selection in the tree.  According to the spec a flag of
TVGN_FIRSTVISIBLE  is also allowed, which attempts to position the tree
so that the given item is the first one visible.  Surfacing this feature via an
API on Tree would allow the profiler to set the item position.  This information

column1: Here's where we were when weleft today:
1. Fix the transparency in Button so that if the user puts a transparent GIF
into a disabled button, at least the shape will be right.
2. Tell the user if they really care about what happens when the button
is disabled (on NT only), store a second bitmap as monochrome and
setImage() the button when you disable it.
After talking with SWT, we have an alternative story. The whole
Image.setBackground() story has problem from the start; consider
the case where widget colors change, for example - to get it right we'd have to
hook callbacks and notify the user, etc etc etc.
As well, we are making the user (and ourselves) work too hard, since
none of the native controls on any platform support such a thing. So the
1. Claim absolutely no support for transparent GIFs in any widget.
2. Still support loading GIFs, and do the right thing when drawing them in a GC.
3. If set into a widget, a GIF would simply be treated like any other bitmap,
the transparency information would be ignored.
4. If the user desires to have transparent images in a widget, then they will
use Icons (either by loading from ICO or doing some magic to convert - loading
from an ICO seems more reasonable). Native windows controls supports this
1. Changing the system colors would work; the transparency would be
maintained, and we wouldn't have to fart about telling the user to change
2. Simplification of API. (setBackground is kind of weird)
3. We wouldn't be confusing to the user as to the capabilities of the platform
4. We wouldn't have to do all kinds of extra work to disable the image etc.
1. Users would have to convert their GIFs to ICOs.
2. Since Motif doesn't support transparency at all, we still haven't completely
solved the motif story, but we have simplified it since they wouldn't have to
We are already claiming no support in the widgets for transparent GIFs.
This is exactly the reason why they have to set the background color.
If we tell them to use icons instead we are setting ourselves up for a trap
when we run into platforms that only support fixed size icons.
Drawing transparent gifs correctly in the GC is already supported. This
support can not be removed. The problem is with the widgets and
deciding how best to support this. Here are the constraints as I see them:

column2: 1) We must enable users to set arbitrary sized transparent images into
2) Drawing must be fast. Any preprocessing has to happen when the image
Not when the control is being displayed. (ie. No owner draw crap to
3) When the widget is disabled we have to do something reasonable.

4) I would prefer not to have widgets have to manage copies of these

column1: 4460,James_Moody@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T18:17:09Z,0,0,There are many cases in our API where we incorrectly use the Point
class simply because it encapsulates two integers. In many of these
situations, we really want an Interval class (with fields start and end),
or a Dimension class (with fields width and height).
Image.getBounds() should return a Dimension instead of a Rectangle, since
an Image has no x or y value, just width and height.
Text.getSelection() should return an Interval instead of a Point, since the
selection has no x or y values, just start and end.
There are many other cases where this incorrect mapping occurs, and it
can cause confusion over the actual semantics of API. In the example above,
does getSelection() actually return me the row and column of the selected
text? I might think so, since a point has x and y values. The addition of a
couple of simple domain objects and the changing of some of our API now might
make things easier for the user later.

column3: All true, but the current patterns are in keeping with our minimalist
view of API. No action taken at this time."

column1: 4460,dlwhiteman@us.ibm.com,2001-11-19T17:33:41Z,2,0,Let me add my ""vote"" to James' comments.  Making an OO library usable requires
good naming, and ""x"" and ""y"" are simply not good names for the cases that James
outlines above.  This concern was also raised by chemi_ordax@yahoo.com on the
It is (IMHO) poor OO design to think about a class purely in terms of the data
it encapsulates. Classes have both *data* and behaviour. A Point encapsulates an
(x,y) point in coordinate space, sure; but it has the potential to do more than
that, such as offer the ability to translate() the point to a different (x,y)
location. If Point is also being used to represent Dimension, does it make sense
to have a Dimension.translate()? Or a Point.grow()? No, of course not.
The current API may be minimalist, but to be minimalist to the point of
excluding functionality seems to be shooting yourself in the foot. I've entered
feature request #13950 as a potential solution."
4460,Mike_Wilson@ca.ibm.com,2002-04-17T13:28:47Z,4,0,"This entire discussion presupposes that an SWT Point is somehow related to the
more mathematically oriented ""Point"" you find in AWT and elsewhere. You need
to understand that this is *not* such a beast.
In SWT a Point is simply a data structure with two slots, used to pass values
to OS routines which require that shape. It does not have interesting API,
since the operating systems SWT is built also do not.
Just so you know, the ""poor OO design"" Colin is talking about is actually >15
years (separately, by multiple people) of serious, practical experience
dealing with the problems of directly interfacing OO languages with non-OO
windowing systems. If his experience with this problem is comparable, he
should apply to work for OTI.
4460,dlwhiteman@us.ibm.com,2002-04-17T13:42:51Z,5,0,Perhaps it should have a different name, since the class name Point suggests
either the mathematical Point or the AWT Point (or both).  The name certainly
doesn't suggest a ""two slot data structure"", and also doesn't have descriptive
names for the variables when used for things like ""height"" and ""width""."
4460,sharples@nz1.ibm.com,2002-04-17T21:48:14Z,6,0,"If Point is just a data structure of two ints, why not get rid of it altogether,
and just use an int[2] (and int[4] instead of Rectangle)?
The thing is, to the OS (and to the SWT designer), it is just two ints. To the
SWT *user*, though, it is a class just like any other. In my *limited*
experience of programming GUIs in OO languages, it is extremely helpful to think
about what you are modelling in pure OO terms, even if what's going on in the
actual windowing system is non-OO and doesn't care about classes. An API which
assists you in doing that is very useful.
I'm not trying to suggest that SWT as a whole is badly designed. On the
contrary, it is extremely well-designed and implemented. I have abandoned Swing
altogether in favour of SWT, and I'm sure many others will do likewise. However,
there are certain aspects of the SWT API that are not very user-friendly. An
experienced SWT user probably doesn't worry about such things, particularly if
they're used to dealing with the nitty-gritty OS level. Learners like myself, on
the other hand, can find it a bit frustrating.
I think that SWT could easily become part of the core Java language, as an
alternative or complement to (not replacement for) AWT/Swing. I hope the SWT
team don't feel they have to position SWT as a competitor to AWT."
4460,Mike_Wilson@ca.ibm.com,2002-04-18T13:57:31Z,7,0,"Actually, we could have used an array of two ints, except for one small detail
which is internal to the implementation: when native API is called, it
translates the representation of ""Point"" arguments between the Java memory
layout and the OS specific layout by doing getIntField calls
(see ""getPOINTFields"" in the file ""structs.c""). Although these could have been
coded as array references instead, the current code matches the pattern used
for all the other ""classes which are really structs"", which seems like a good
idea given how important consistancy is when working at this low level.
I understand the point you are making about thinking in OO versus OS terms.
All I can say is, our current philosophy is to, as much as possible, avoid
adding new concepts and features which do not model directly some platform
funtionality. Our two biggest exceptions to this rule, the typed listener
support in org.eclipse.swt.events and the custom widgets in
org.eclipse.swt.custom, were both done only after a great deal of discussion
in which we finally convinced ourselves that we could not provide a first-
Similarly, I *do* appreciate the discussion we are having here. You'll have to

column1: 4463,carolynmacleod4@gmail.com,2001-10-11T18:17:12Z,0,0,"Why does the cursor change from an I beam to an arrow after something is selected in a RichText?

column2: Is it supposed to be for drag & drop? If so, why is it disabled?

column3: Yes, it's supposed to be for drag and drop.  Drag and drop is disabled because
it is hard/impossible to make it work with modify/verify.  I haven't tried to work
around the cursor changing.  I didn't think is was important.
Does drag and drop work now? If so, can we move this PR to fixed?
Now that DND is implemented, you can drag text from a Rich Text widget.  Note however, that you must first
create a DragSource for the widget.  Unfortunately, once you make the Rich Text widget a DragSource, you can
no longer drag to select text in that widget.  If you do not create a DragSource for the widget, dragging will select the
text and the cursor will not change to an arrow (it will remain an I beam).
Nothing has been done about this."

column2: - was running this way for several hours, and performance was degrading fairly seriously.

column3: i.e. I was seeing usually about 85% - 87% memory usage, and more and more often the CPU would go into the 100% busy mode.

column2: - decided that I could take it no longer, so I decided to exit my ""inner"" LeapFrog (intending to exit the ""outer"" one afterwards and reboot).

column3: (if it helps any, my ""inner"" workspace was a fairly small, J9/JCL-based workspace with IBM Embedded Examples in it)

column2: Got the following dialog (presumably from the OS <g>:

column3: The instruction at ""0x0968d7d6"" referenced memory at ""0x0000007c"".
Click on OK to terminate the application.
(don't you hate it when 'OK' is your only choice <g>)

column2: Being paranoid, and assuming that (a) my ""inner"" LF was a goner, and (b) as soon as I clicked on OK
I might lose the ""outer"" LF as well, I decided to see if I could sneak in and exit the ""outer"" LF before
clicking on the OK button. I thought I was home free because I got past File->Exit (yes, save), and my
machine proceeded to swap gloriously for a very long time (which I naively thought was the sound of saving).
But it never finished. It's hung.
Might as well click on the OK button now and see what happens.
Sure enough, it killed my ""outer"" LF, but in its last dying gasp in the DOS window, I saw an exception flash by
(it was only for a second - I did not have time to copy/paste it or anything).
It was a NullPointerException in something like ""AbstractVMLauncher"".
Sorry I don't have anything more to go on than that.

column3: Astoundingly, my ""inner"" LF workspace was ok. It wasn't even locked. Bizzarre.
Collected some stats, in case it helps at all.
With basically only the OS and task manager running (of course, there are always other little 'TSR's running too, but nothing big):
After LF 313 jar is started, with only Workbench up:
After opening MSMail, RPRS, 5 other LF browsers, and starting up my ""inner"" LF again (this is what I had up when I crashed):
With all of the above, plus MS Explorer, plus the ""inner"" debugger up (this is what I had up most of the time today):
The 3 mem usage numbers that I noted in the (approx) hour before crashing were: 80%, 85%, 87%
and also I had one of the NT ""Running low on Virtual Memory"" dialogs at one point.
Sorry, didn't take note of the handles.
Wow - I got it *again*. Same dialog, same hex numbers, even. And I got it trying to exit the ""inner"" LF,
just like last time. Both times, I was debugging the ""inner"" debugger, and got a walkback in the ""outer"" console.
Both times, I closed the ""inner"" debugger, and tried to exit/save the ""inner"" LF.
My memory usage numbers are lower (I don't have Explorer up any more, and my ""inner"" LF is probably not taking up any resources at this time):
This time, I didn't try to exit the ""outer"" LF - I just saved the workspace. It was fine.

been something mixed in with all those stack traces.
Sorry I can't be any more help.

column1: 4473,Mike_Wilson@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T18:17:23Z,0,0,AWT has it's own layout managers.  Since it is not using the SWT layouts and is doing layout
at a different time (i.e. not inside the resize event), we need a mechanism to indicate when
we are doing layout so that we can stop the OS from responding to every size change
being made in the widgets during layout.
Currently there is no way to do this.  It would be nice to have this in the form of two calls
that can begin and end deferring of layout on a Composite.

column2: Why is this a problem?  Do other implementations of AWT have such a mechanism?
I believe that you are really seeing a problem and I'd like to know what it is.
It is a performance problem, since the OS posts events back during layout (WM_SIZE).
Yes, other implementations have the mechanism.
Can you describe it or point me to some code?

4476,Mike_Wilson@ca.ibm.com,2001-10-11T18:17:26Z,0,0,"When scrolling a slider for example, it is not possible to syncExec runnables from
any other thread and have them run until the scroll thumb is released.  This means users
can not write code to respond to slider events during scrolling, nor can they do any
other work on widgets created in that thread, assuming that most calls through AWT use
It appears that the OS creates a separate loop to read and dispatch events during scrolling and
our (AWT) readAndDispatch loop waits, as a side effect of waiting runAsyncMessages is not called
during this time.  We made a quick hack to post a special message to ourselves whenever a new
syncExec runnable was added and when the windowProc saw that message it would run one async
runnable, this gave acceptable behaviour (we are not saying it is any sort of solution).
NOTE: Scrolling is ONE example of this problem.

column3: There is a problem doing this in VA/Java because ""no context switch in call-in"" which means

We can test the fix and you could wrap the code in a isVAJava flag or something.

If full window drag is ON and you have a window that paints itself (non native widgets), it
